content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												When I was younger, my gramdma came over to my house to hang out. She was a "OG gamer grill", so we played a lot of the same games. When ever Fable TLC came out she fell in love with it, so she made a pirated copy for my 12 yr old self. I installed the game on my dinky little pc and started playing it immediately. When I started out in Oakvale, the graphics where so demanding (for my POS rig at the time) that the ground looked like snow and the water was♥♥♥♥♥♥yellow, but I still played it anyways. I, too, fell in love with Albion's quirky humour. A few weeks later my dad bought me a graphics card so there would be no more♥♥♥♥♥♥oceans. I learned a few things about PCs because of it. So I played Fable for months and when I finally beat it, I was so happy. The story is so great and the gameplay is amazing! I then played the game two more times, leveling up different skills along the way. I had a good guy knight, a neutral rogue, and an evil wizard. This game ment so much to me because my grandma gave it to me. She got upset when I told her I beat it before she did, so I teased her about it forever :)I bought this game for nostalgia reasons, and also because it reminds me of my awesome grandma. I miss her... <3

												I was stuck in Havana, Cuba for 2 weeks.  That city (and country) is a cesspool.  I was starving, sick, tired, and angry.  I was also cut off from electronic civilization.  No email.  No internet.  No phones.  No nothing.  It so happened that I had this game installed on my laptop and was able to play it in offline mode.  Accordingly, the hours I played this game were not clocked on my profile, but believe me...THIS GAME IS AMAZING.  It is older, but it maintains it's classic status.  For 2 weeks straight, the only pleasure I found in life was playing this game and roof drinking.  Do yourself a favor and buy this game.  Now.

number of helpful: 188 of 207 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Fable. Yo. The Lost Chapters.Alright where do I start?This game was my CHILDHOOD.I PULLED MY FIRST ALL NIGHTER BY MYSELF PLAYING FABLE THE LOST CHAPTERS ON THE ORIGINAL XBOX. If that isn't love, then I really don't know what is.Let's get down to it.Pros:-Fun combat. Sort of basic hack n' slash action rpg fare. Now I love to be rewarded for me kills. Typo was unintenional but I'll leave it there.      So you got SWORDS, BOWS & ARROWS, AND CROSSBOWS, and MAGIC! For each type of way you eradicate your enimies, you get experience for that category of killing. So, if you bash a hobbe's brains out with a hammer, you'll get melee experience, then stick in between the eyes with an arrow, you'll get ranged experience, and then finish him off by burning him to a crisp with a fireball, you'll get magic experience. And to put icing on the cake, whenever you finish off an enemie, or an innocent civillian, whatever, you'll get general experience. HOW EXCITING.        Melee combat comes down to left clicking, blocking, dodging, and doing cool overpowered attacks with the right click when your weapon lights up. Ranged is holding down the left click to draw and charge your weapon then popping heads from afar. Magic is self explanatory even more so than the other categories. Do your thing, Harry. You are the chosen one.-There are a lot of spells. Lightning, teleporting, reviving the undead, being a jedi and unleashing the wrath of hell.-Obvious character evolution! Not only do you feel your character getting stronger but you can also see it. Upgrade your strength and become The Hulk. Upgrade your skills and become Shaq, because you get tall when you kill enemies with a crossbow or scam someone out of their money, because hormones work like that. Use magic and you'll turn into a super saiyan. No lie.         Another example of that character evolution would be your morality. I think morality systems in video games are dope. If you're nice, you'll get a pretty little halo will float above your head, butterflies will hoard you, and you'll grow angelicly. If you're evil and kill your sister lol, you'll grow horns and people will cower in fear.-Chicken helmet. 'Nuff said.-Story's a little cliched, but only really the beginning. You play some as some kid who's village gets burnt to the ground by bandits but a wizard saves and takes you to meet a short Hulk Hogan, who raises you to be a hero. The story then turns out to be a lot bigger than story of just vengeance will the balance of Albion hanging in your hands.-The game doesn't take itself TOO seriously. There are serious moments but the overall tone and atmosphere of most of the zones is all laid back and chill.-Soundtrack's pretty dope too.Cons:-The game's ugly. "Oh, Levi, the game is ten years old," well, I DON'T CARE. The game has not aged well. It didn't look good ten years ago. Deal with it. Anniversary edition looks beautimous though.-Its pretty short. I don't have an exact estimate of how quickly I got EVERYTHING DONE in the game, but I got all the sidequests done, max'd skills, fully geared, ect and started a second playthrough in less than 30 hours.-Your morality and story choices don't have a huge impact on the world. Yes, there are consequences for killing an important character at some point in the story, but it all really boils down to that the life you took was expendable anyway and their death would've decided whether people would talk smack to you or applaud you. Other than that though, the story is basically the same regardless of choices and the two endings are very slightly different.-The game is really linear, zones are small and there a little opprotunities to go off the beaten path. However, if you can find a place to explore, you will most likely be rewarded.In a nutshell, the game has a good but cliche story, fun combat, and you can get experience by eating meat. Buy it. Or the Anniversary edition for Xbox 360.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Fable The Lost Chapters is an old Xbox port with some extra bits.The game has you playing through the story of a boy turned man who becomes either a hero or a villian.Like many of Peter Molyneux's games you have the constant choices during quest to do good deeds or evil ones.The world around you reflects which side you choose and your characters appearance changes .The story itself is interesting enough but its the storytelling presentation that won me over.Weapons,skills & abilities in the game are your choice never being forced to pick any over another.They all have strengths and weaknesses but none outclass the others,other than in terms of damage.There are various outfits ,armors ,collectibles ,tropheys,and acclaim status to be gotten as you play.You can buy houses & rent them,barter for profit, get married,get divorced in the game as well.The game world is linear but the world itself is decently sized and you will revisit area's often enough.The game sports teleporting from anywhere to specific nodes to help keep the ending running down well enough.The game is littered with humor and sidequests many of which the rewards are worth doing but completely skippable. For an old game its a good buy if you have never played it and want a decent linear action rpg.With a sweetfx mod the game looks even better. Get it 75% off on the cheap or get Fable Anniversary with all its new shiney looks.Either way worth that linear playthrough if you like rpgs.

number of helpful: 84 of 86 people (98%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Probably one of my favourite games of all time. I'm not a hardcore gamer though.First things first, don't judge this game based from experience from Fable 2, Fable 3 or the journey.The original Fable and the TLC edition are by far the best of the series and they started removing elements from the game such as the loss of a mana bar in Fable 2 and the health bar in Fable 3.Why is this game awesome?This game was one of the best of the Fable series thus far. It included the ability to slice your own destiny giving you the option to go full out evil with horns and flies buzzing around you or the choice of being good, being rewarded with a halo and popularity amongst the people of Albion. This game really emphasises the choice of your morality alignment, whether you wanted to have fun running around trying to take on guards or sacrificing people in order to receive a weapon; to just being able to stay clean and donating to the Temple.What is it like?This game is a sick Action Role-play game where the player gets to control a character and goes around bashing things with a sword swell as casting spells and spamming expressions to random villagers. While the environments aren't massive like the newer games they are sufficient and they are good enough for a basic casual gamer (like myself, they are pretty big to roam). The best thing about this game is being able to see character development. You start as a weak puny character that is a stick compared to the beast you become after you finish the storyline. It's a lot of fun mucking around with abilities.Apart from the main story line which has some really intense kicks and shakes the player can also buy out properties and steal stuff all the actions you make do change your morality which is probably the biggest aspect as I mentioned before. This game is worth more than it's price on steam and I really do highly commender it. Either TLC or the original edition, they are both beast :)

number of helpful: 83 of 88 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												My thoughts on Fable - The lost Chapters:I've played this game a lot when I was younger and didn't have Steam yet, that's why it says I've not played it at all and I'm still writing this recommendation. I got this game during a sale just because of the nostalgic feeling and so that I could tell you what an awesome game this is.Fable was released on PC back in 2005 and got a lot of attention back then because of the freedom it gives the player and the impacts those decisions can and will have on both your character and the environment, which was a pretty much unknown feature.You start the game as a young boy who's given several tasks, during which you're already forced to decide wther you want to finish them on the good or the bad way. Then, after some events, another tutorial and lots of talking, you're a grown up man who's (amongst other things) trying to figure out why those events happened and who's responsible for your parents death. You'll be given several quests, you may explore the world and fight numerous enemies, gain exp and gain access to bigger and better spells (which can be upgraded too), weapons (which can also be upgraded, giving them some awesome visual effects) and armor. Houses can be bought, women married (and f*cked, though the screen becomes black), chicked can be kicked around, and whole cities can be murdered.Cool thing about this game is, it always gives the player a choice. You can play it as a good guy, where you always help the innocent, never steal anything and never kill anyone who didn't deserve it. The more good things you do, the more saint-like your hero becomes, until you have your own halo and literally fart butterflies.If you do things the evil way, your character grows horns, becomes pale and scares the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everyone he encounters which makes getting a woman to marry you the most difficult task in the game (still a better love story than Twilight!). You can save a lot of money though by simply stealing the things that you need, and murdering an entire city is ♥♥♥♥ing funny! The hero also adapts to the weapons you use - if you fight with spells most of the time, your arms start glowing, but if you use swords, you'll become a big beefy warrior. Eat much, and you'll become fat, but eat nothing and you'll be thin as a branch.For a game that old the graphics and dialogues are still pretty good, the soundtrack is great and you'll be entertained for several hours. There may be lots of quests that are nothing special at all, but the freedom you enjoy in between is what makes this game one of the best I've played so far.There aren't many bad things I can remember because it's been a while since I've last played it, but be sure not to be playing a perfect game. It has its flaws like any other game, but I can't remember anything that makes me want to say "♥♥♥♥ this game".There seems to be a HD remake of this game on the way (no idea when though), but as someone commented below, only for the Xbox. Don't sue me if that's wrong.Buy it and enjoy!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												This is my favourite, and the best, RPG of all time. Period.Yes, I have no game time right now - but don't judge the review on that just yet.I remember back when I was younger, my brother had an Original Xbox, and Fable had just come out. He'd tell me how amazing it was and I always wanted to play it when he wasn't. After fighting to, I finally got to play and it was amazing. I'd spend all my free time on it when he wasn't using his xbox and it was just the best game I had ever played!As an earlier birthday present one year, I got to choose between an Xbox or a Nintendo DS - Yes I chose the correct choice - I bought an Xbox Original for the sole reason of spending my days on Fable. Fable is an amazing game, you make choices, buy and sell and collect items, weapons and armour. You have many expressions to make and learn, keys to find, chests to unlock and a lot of enemies to kill before killing the pfft..."Almighty" End-Game boss. Fable as a whole was an amazing experience. Not so long after, Fable: The Lost Chapters was released, which I bought the day it came out. There weren't a lot of changes, flourishes were a different colour, Mini-map updates, some extra quests and optimisations, but of course, because it was Fable, it never stopped me spending countless hours playing it.Fable: The Lost Chapters, - or Fable TLC as some refer as - was a great experience, especially a small 'DLC - like' continuation of the game where the original Fable finished off. It's great and adds some extra lore and beef to the existing story, some new armour and Demon Doors as well as new expressions. The games in their entireties are amazing, and if you have never played either of them, then you should or we can't be friends.I have a lengthy review on Fable Anniversary, which in my opinion is also great. Especially since the Develiopers were kind enough to release a load of patches to improve on it where players were not happy.10/10. Best RPG of all time.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Despite the tedious combat, this is a really good RPG game. It's somewhat short and quite linear, but there's enough interesting content in it to keep you busy for at least 20 hours. While a lot of the features are a tad superfluous. there is a good story, plenty of quests and a lot of interesting places to visit. The moral choices you have to make really add to the game. The only downside of the game is that the (melee) combat is just a lot of clicking. The training about blocking that you receive early in the game is rendered completely useless because you're (almost) always attacked by more than one enemy. Still it only lengthens the battles and doesn't really make them harder.Recommended for 10$ and a no-brainer for anybody who likes RPGs when it's on sale.

												This is the first time I've played a Fable game andI enjoyed this game mostly, I liked the story and that you could do bad, or good things or both. number of helpful: 26 of 26 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												When I thought about games that stand the test of time, the first game that came to my mind was Fable- The Lost Chapters. It was one of the first games I played and I spent hours upon hours playing it. So when I bought it on steam, I was somewhat sceptic. Would it live up to my childhood nostalgia or would it ruin a fond memory?You might have already guessed the answer from the intro, and you're right - it did live up to the nostalgia. The game have a certain charm I haven't found in another game. I personally love the skill/magic/combat system and how the leveling functions. The gameplay is very accepting, yet it's challenging in some parts of the story/game. You'll have a relaxing and fun experience with it.   There is a moral "dilemma" in the game, do you walk righteous path of a saint or do you walk the path of evil and slaughter? I very much enjoy this dilemma. Sure, it is very simple and there has since been countless games with similar and more "advanced" systems implemented. Yet, I still tend to like the one in Fable more. It affects your interaction with npc's, some game mechanics, clothing, your character and parts of the story. Throughout the game, you'll have some big and some smaller choices (e.g. in the beginning of the game, you can find a fellow cheating on his wife. You can decide to tell his wife - good, or you can keep a secret and get money - evil). As this was my first review, it might lack in certain areas but bear with me. All in all, I 100% recommend this pearl. Yes, it does fall short in some aspects due to its age and it might not have the same effect on you as it had on me, but give it a chance. You will not be disappointed.

number of helpful: 32 of 39 people (82%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Fable: The Lost Chapters is a 2005 re-release of the 2004 killer app Fable, brought to you by Lionhead studios - a studio famous for this, having Molyneux as a creative director, and having Molyneux as a creative director who lies.Luckily the 2005 release places it outside of recent memory, so we can ignore all promises of real-time tree growth, multiplayer and multiple guilds, and get on with the game proper. This is not a blind review. First played this game near release, and remembered it being incredibly mediocre. How's that for a first impression? As it turns out, it was just the memory that was mediocre. "Your health is low. Do you have any potions, or food?"  - GuildmasterBy combining all three virtues/playstyles - Strength, Skill, Will - you'll end up with a character that forms many unfinished wholes into an Ultron of tolerability. Going for a specific "build" is not fun, limiting yourself is not fun, the only way to really squeeze some playability out of it is to throw it into a smoothie. Abandon all delusions of sticking to a single path, you're a spellswordbowman. With that out of the way, the game has more to it than you'd initially expect. Will gives you a dozen tools for every situation, Strength keeps you in the action with little touches like rolling having i-frames and the guard-breaking flourishes that I swear trigger at random, and Skill supplements the other two with speed and money.At times, especially during endgame when you've completely broken the game to become a regular munchkin, I was having legitimate fun with the gameplay alone. Something not expected from the half-remembered aeons of strafing/kiting at a distance, or continually bouncing off an enemy's impregnable defense.But it's sloppier than a pig's feeding trough. Movement isn't remotely 1-1, there's no combos beyond mash attack, no way to play gracefully or precise at all. Enemy attacks either telegraph from a mile away, have just enough startup to seemingly knock you out of wailing on them, or in some amazing circumstances are completely messy distance attacks with no way to predict them at all, just react.Accept that you will be spamming your go-to preferred glorified macro lategame and you'll be happier.  "Try to get your combat multiplier even higher."  - GuildmasterWhat's there is there, but Fable has largely sold itself on character morphing. Which is okay. A bit ridiculous, you'll end up twice the size of the average character and shrivelled to a prune while the tykes at the local school still take their first lessons. There's not nearly as much character customization as you'd think - maybe 25 outfits, 10 haircuts and a handful of supplementary aspects, you'll rest easy in the knowledge that your super special Hero is going to turn out about the same as everyone else's.The only real morphing here is of your expectations, and with no way to roll back level upgrades you're probably going to end up with a stature you're unhappy with regardless.It's fundementally a silly game, which is fine except that means that any attempt to appear serious falls flat on its face. All the lore ends in abrupt handwaves with no payoff (Did you know that Jack of Blades is a primordial horror-demon, despite just being a smug trickster ingame you trip over and OHKO?), all the character art angles more towards the era's World of Warcraft domineered sensibilities instead of more traditional aesthetics - fine if you like that - and all the music is consistently great there's no dissing these tunes. "There's a Quest Card waiting for you at the Guildhall."  - GuildmasterUltimately what Fable is, is a surprisingly mechanically fun but otherwise shallow and cliched RPG. Much like Molyneux's hopes and dreams, it aimed for the moon and landed amongst the dirt.  A final sidenote, it'll run on just about anything but you're going to have to do some moderate legwork. Deleting codecs, adjusting administrator privileges, the like.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
English Version: It was given to me about a year ago and I was pretty skeptic at first, but after playing it I had to change my mind; this game is amazing.The plot is simple but nice. It tells the story of a young hero after his village, Oakvale, is raided by bandits. He's rescued by a hero, Daedalus, who leads him to the Guild of Heroes, where he meets Whisper, his roommate. After years of training, he becomes a hero and goes out on his adventure.The gameplay is varied and is mainly based on two main aspects; ''Experience'' and ''Personality''.Regarding experience we can choose, after the tutorial training, to specialize in "Strength", "Skill" and "Will". The first is related to health, strength and physique; we receive "Strength" experience points whenever we fight hand to hand, thus allowing us to improve it. The second is related to agility, precision and cunning; we will be awarded "Skill" experience points whenever we practice ranged combat, and as a result we will be able to improve ranged capabilities. The last is related to three different types of spells; attack (targeting the opponent), environmental (targeting surroundings, such as being able to slow or stop time) and physical (targeting ourselves, with powers such as healing spells or shields).Regarding personality there are four different factors: morality, fame, charm and scariness. Morality is linked to the choices that we make during the game, usually either good or bad. Fame is linked to the missions that we have to do: if we taking challenges, we will acquire more fame if we succeed, but we will lose money if we were to fail the challenge. The charm and scariness are related to the physical aspect that we will have in our character (tattoos, clothing, haircut) and are mostly opposites.In addition, the gameplay is full of sidequests that improve immersion in the game's universe, and allow us to enjoy fantastic locations. Besides, the possibility of betting on the missions to acquire more fame and money makes it even more fun for me.Then let's talk about the possibility of getting married to an entire city. How's that? Overall it's a nice game and I recommend it fully!Italian Version: Mi è stato regalato circa lo scorso anno ed ero abbastanza scettica inizialmente, ma dopo averlo giocato mi son dovuta ricredere; è un gioco a dir poco stupendo.La trama è semplice ma carina. Racconta la storia di un giovane eroe rimasto solo dopo l'attacco al suo villaggio, Oakvale, da parte di banditi. Viene tratto in salvo da un eroe, Dedalo, e portato alla Gilda degli Eroi, dove conoscerà Sussurro, la sua compagna di stanza. Dopo anni di allenamento, diventa un eroe e parte per la sua avventura.Il gameplay è molto vario e si basa principalmente su due aspetti principali; ''Esperienza'' e ''Personalità''.Riguardo all'esperienza possiamo scegliere, dopo l'allenamento iniziale, di specializzarci tra ''Forza'', ''Abilità'' e ''Volontà''. La prima è mirata alla salute, alla resistenza ed al fisico; ci vengono dati punti esperienza ''forza'' ogni qualvolta utilizziamo un combattimento corpo a corpo, e quindi ci migliorerà sullo stesso. La seconda è formata da agilità, precisione ed astuzia; ci verranno assegnati punti 'abilità'' ogni qualvolta usiamo il combattimento a distanza, e di conseguenza ci aiuterà nello stesso. L'ultima invece è formata da tre tipi di incantesimo; d'attacco (ovvero mirato all'avversario), ambientale (mirato invece all'ambiente, come fermare il tempo) e fisici (che è mirato a noi stessi, come incantesimi di cura o di scudo).Riguardo alla personalità invece possiamo trovare quattro aspetti: personalità, fama, fascino e spavento. La personalità è legata alle azioni che compiano nel gioco, ovvero alla classica scelta ''buono'' o ''cattivo''. La fama è legata alle missioni che portiamo a termine, scommettendoci sopra ne acquisiremo di più, ma perderemo soldi nel caso dovessimo perdere la scommessa. Il fascino e lo spavento sono legate all'aspetto fisico che faremo avere al nostro personaggio (tatuaggi, vestiario, taglio di capelli) ed uno esclude l'altro, ovviamente!Inoltre, il gameplay, è pieno di sidequest che aiutano l'esplorazione del gioco, e ci permettono di godere di ambientazioni fiabesche. Inoltre la possibilità di scommettere sopra le missioni, che siano principali o secondarie, per acquisir fama e soldi, rende tutto molto più divertente, secondo me.E poi vogliamo parlare della possibilità di sposarci un'intera città? Nel complesso è un gran bel gioco e quindi lo consiglio pienamente!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												This is not a proper review of the game, but in its place I will tell a story. This story will include a few spoilers, but let's be honest- the game is from 2004, the story will most likely have been spoiled for you at some point.Let us begin. There once was a boy, brought into the great Guild of Heroes at a very young age, who trained hard night and day, dedicating his life to becoming a great Hero, seeking fame and glory. Even as a child the Hero was very boastful- proud of his physical and mental prowess and always seeking recognition for his accomplishments. But then one day the Hero took a boast that would later prove to humble him; the day had come that he enter the Arena, and the prideful Hero raised himself upon the podium outside the Guild's walls, looked down into the cheering crowd below.This was, by this time, a familiar sight, for in his search for glory the Hero was not satisfied with merely completing a Quest. He would stand upon the platform and utter the most outrageous of boasts, at one time defeating an entire pack of Balverines stark naked without taking a single scratch as a personal test of his agility. His pride knew no bounds, and the Hero took upon himself the title of the divine Avatar, claiming that he would be the sword which the Gods wielded to drive back the darkness. However, this day the Hero saw an opportunity to forge a truly legendary tale within the Arena, one which could never possibly be surpassed: he would enter the Arena and slay all that came before him, be it man or beast, completely unprotected, and without a so much as a scratch to mar his rosy skin. The crowd cheering and his chest puffed with pride, the Hero set off to the Isle of Witchwood, and the Arena therein.The Hero entered the Arena to the roaring of a crowd that could only brought on by the anticipation of imminent bloodshed. A veteran of the bloodied sands had just fallen, adding yet another entry in the long list of those who had died in pursuit of glory through combat. The Hero made short work of an entire nest of Wasps, then of a clan of Hobbes, all singlehandedly. From the third round on he would be joined by a fellow Hero to defeat the beasts that were released upon him. The gate lowered and from beyond came his greatest rival, a Heroine by the name of Whisper who had looked upon him with disdain ever since they had begun their training together many years ago. However, the Hero was satisfied with this, as it would only add to his legend, and so together they set about cutting down a pack of Balverines to pieces. By this time he had set into the familiar groove of combat, and with spell and sword his foes fell before him.The Hero did not blink an eye as the remains of those who had died on the sands of the Arena tore themselves from the blood soaked earth and rose to reclaim their glory in death. After dispatching the Undead, a clan of Bandits, once feared throughout all of Albion and slated for execution within the Arena several years ago were next. Methodically he dodged their blows and cut them down one by one, Whisper his constant companion this a whirlwind of blood and blade. By this point it had become apparent that group tactics were no match for the Heroes' skill, and so the master of the Arena swiftly changed tactics and introduced a matched pair of trolls to the audience. The Heroes had already faced Trolls before, so as they saw the rumbling of the earth and the giant hands of stone emerge from the sod they knew what to expect. Cool and calm, they circled their prey, waiting for the opportune moment to strike and avoiding the attacks of the other troll. First a pair of Earth Trolls fell beneath their blades, then the even tougher Rock Trolls, chipped at repeatedly by their hit and run attacks.With the defeat of the Trolls the Heroes stood tall, knowing they could take on anything. With the end near, the question of who the gold would go to should they win, as the Arena can only have one Champion,  arose, but this thought was quickly purged from minds as a massive creature the likes of which they had never seen before clawed its way out of the sands, stinger raised and claws snapping. The beast, a gigantic scorpion, was called Arachanox, and many a Champion candidate had fallen before her, their aspirations crushed along with their bodies under its massive stinger. This threat was novel, something the Heroes had never faced before, and it took a great amount of teamwork to learn its strengths and weaknesses. Carefully, they paced around it, dodging out of the way and poking at is when they could. The Hero had managed to maintain his boast of being untouched up until this point, as familiar foes had patterns which he could exploit. But in the face of the unknown his abilities remained sharp, but even the most skilled warrior eventually makes a mistake. Learning the patterns of the great beast the Hero hacked at it with his greatsword when it was stunned, retreating from the slashing of its pincers when it freed itself. They repeated this, but the long hours of combat had begun to wear on them, and the inevitable happened: the Hero made a mistake. Thinking the beast dead after an especially powerful blow, he raised his sword to the sky in celebration, to the delight of the crowd. But Arachanox was not yet defeated, and in its death throes it struck the Hero from behind, putting an end to his long line of successful boasts. Angered by the ruin of the legend he was trying to forge, he turned and struck it down, making sure it was dead, then turned to the cheering crowd.Above them appeared none other than the legendary Jack of Blades to commend them for their valour. However, with his praise came a final, deadly, proposition: one final round. There could only be one Champion of the Arena, Unable to refuse this challenge or lose all they had just fought for, Whisper turned to the Hero and said that she could not kill him, not after all that they had been through in the Arena. The Hero then recalled his earlier boasting, declaring that he would cut down all he faced on the sands. He was a good man at heart, but he realized that his hubris had led him to this situation. Whisper's voice broke him from his thoughts, declaring that they should at the very least put on a good show. And so they crossed blades, once rivals, then allies, and now as reluctant foes on the field of battle. Whisper's skill proved to be no match for that of the Hero in the end, and as she kneeled in the sands, beaten, the Hero had a decision to make: would he sacrifice this woman who had caused him so much anger and betray the bond forged between them in battle to salvage at least some semblance of the legend he had hoped to create? As he looked down at her, he realized that he could not take the final blow and sheathed his blade, turning from the jeers of the disappointed crowd and the pleading eyes of Whisper to walk silently through the gates. With this he took an oath to never boast again, and became a true Champion of Righteousness, rather than a slave to the battlefield, going on to forge a legacy befitting the title of Avatar.

Posted: March 17
												This is the real deal.  I chose Fable - The Lost Chapters over Fable Anniversary simply because this is the game I remember playing so many years ago on the original Xbox.  This has the classic look and gameplay that I crave, regardless of the polish on Anniversary.  I just bought this today for $9.99 on Steam and I couldn't be happier with my purchase.  It's not a big deal but I do wish it was controller compatible (I play most of my pc games with a PS4 Dualshock controller) but the WASD control type is fine and it's nice to set hotkeys to say, additional buttons on your mouse.  If you loved the original Fable, adorably dated graphics & all, this game is for you!  If you are new to Fable and somewhat archaic visuals from 2 generations ago annoy you, or you absolutely must use a controller, you might feel more comfortable with Anniversary.  Either way it's a great story & a lot of fun...sooo excited to own it again.Runs on Windows 10, I didn't need to adjust compatibility.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												One of the greatest games ever made.Combat targeting is a bit annoying with mouse + keyboard (no controller support) but it gets easier to deal with the longer you play. The rest of the controls are good.Graphics are still good for their age (in my opinion), the comical art style helps it age well. The level design is memorable and the music is amazing. The characters are wonderfully styled, characters all have unique proportions like big hands and feet compared to the rest of their body. Guards have their caps pulled down over their eyes for a stern look, traders wear goofy tall hats, Thunder is a giant warrior.It's great fun watching your own character change as you progress through the game. You become older, more battle hardened, taller and more buff. You have full control over how good or evil your character is and your actions/appearance affect how the world views you. Later quests allow you to make some pretty major moral choices which is nice.The XP and levelling system is simple which is nice. It's quick and easy to level your character based on your playstyle, you don't have to dedicate yourself to one thing. You've got melee weapons, bows, and spells and you can use them all however you like.This is definitely a game everyone should play at least once. Doesn't matter how old it is, it's a classic now. There's plenty to do in the game for a long single playthrough but it also has replayability if you want to try being the opposite of good/bad or inbetween.The beginning of Fable where the Hero starts in Oakvale followed by training at the Guild before being released into Albion will always be one of my favorite gaming moments.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												(Note: My opinion of this game may be biased, since I grew up with it. Nonetheless, I feel the need to represent this game as truthfully and realisticly as possible.)First of all, I played the original Fable on Xbox, so when I saw Lost Chapters on PC, my mind was blown. Lost Chapters is, in a sense, a "DLC" of the original Fable game, in that it adds more content, characters, events, and items. Unfortunately, most of these characters and items won't show up until you complete the first phase of the game.The graphics in this game are admittedly not the greatest. Textures are blurry, people look blocky and pasty, and the landscape turns into this odd, melty blob when you look past mountains and town edges. The characters in this game have a certain charm about them, every one is diverse and unique. From stubborn warriors like Thunder and mysterious people like Briar Rose around every corner, you'll never be short on enemies and friends to make-- by choice, of course. Voice acting quality isn't the best, but usually the actors know what they're doing and can get a point across to you.Combat is... alright, I suppose. If you don't mind taking out the time to redefine your keys in the menu, there's no real problem with it. Some weapons swing oddly, like heavy weapons that FEEL awkward when you use them for the first time, and crossbows that don't fire when you expect them to: zooming in is especially awkward. Boss fights aren't hard, if you just observe and manipulate their patterns, and most minor enemies will run at you, wait a second, and attack, giving you time to fight.And, finally, your character is what you make him into. The game uses the term "Hero" loosely; your character resembles your actions and personality, how you interact with and change the world around you. Those who help people in need and stop bandits and minions get halos and beams of light, while those who slay innocent people and side with thieves and criminals grow horns and walk with flames on their feet.In conclusion, this game is great. It's not short on plot, characters, or choices for you to make. If you have spare time, grab this game, and you won't want to put it down.9/10

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This game is The Hero's Journey: The Game.The quests can get repetitive but the main story is good pulpy stuff. If you grew up watching Hercules, Xena, and/or Highlander, Excalibur, Dragonheart, you'll love it. The gameplay isn't anything extraordinary but it can be fun thwacking hordes of bandits with your BFS spamming Enflame and Multi-Strike. The stealth is unnecessary. Fishing can be tedious, and escort quests suck but all you need is to make them wait, clear out enemies, follow. Magic is fun.What can you do? You can slaughter a village and buy up all the vacated buildings, or you can lead the inhabitants out to a different zone and buy their property if mass murder isn't your thing. You can collect silver keys, treasure clues, and goofy outfits. You can change your PC's hair, tattoos, and clothes. You can grow horns if you go full evil-and you get a halo for being fully good. You can sacrifice innocents for a sick bow, you can trade goods between shops for a limited profit, join Fight Club, show off trophies, shoplift, go fishing, figure out what the hell the demon doors want, and walk around in your Union Jack undies.It's ludicrously easy to gain EXP once you fully understand how the combat multiplier works in conjunction to Physical Shield and how much EXP carrots, red meat, fish, and combat-oriented actions pay out. Hint: eat 150 red meats (3xp) with a x20 multiplier to equal 9000 Physique XP. I wish they hadn't changed Jack of Blades' voice for The Lost Chapters, the original was more menacing. It was like changing Frieza's voice in DBZ Kai. Sure it makes more sense but it's not as cool. Five stars.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												This is THE GAME.On a personal note, I've never enjoyed any game as much as this one.The story... is facinating and makes you want to pursue it all the way to the end without boring you even for a minute. Most quests also give you several choices during them which in turn make your status more evil or more good while twisting the means and/or the end result of quests.Character customization... is well done. You can add tatoos, change your hairstyle, wear different clothes, have battle scars, get older... and all these together decide how NPCs see you and react upon your arrival. You can also get married which usually requires your character to be more attractive and renown.Combat system... your combat skills don't advance along those lame "skill trees" you often see in RPG games. In Fable you can choose everything yourself. If you want to max out all possible skills, go on. If you want to specialize as a combat mage, archer or whatever, you can do it. Also your status will show your combat class depending on which skills you invested your experience into, and there are a lot of classes. Scout, rogue, spellwarrior, witch hunter, fighter, warrior. Just to name a few of them. It's even possible to choose never to train your skills and stay as an "apprentice" all the way to the end game, though this being an expert level challenge.As an action RPG, the game allows you to fully decide how you move, use skills and take on enemy attacks during combat. Changing from spell to another, or from bow to your sword is very simple and doesn't require you to memorize dozens of different buttons for different commands. On a personal note, I've never encountered a combat system anywhere near as fun, exciting yet not too complicated as this one.Well over 20 hours to reach end game unless you rush only the main storyline quests without completing a single side quest along the way, messing with marriages or looking for some of the several legendary weapons hidden throughout the lands of Albion.On a last note. I recommend this over the Anniversary version. Having played both, honestly all I see are a few tweaks to graphics which mainly just make your own character look ugly as hell.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												A very entertaining single player, guided story RPG. There isn't a lot to say for the choices you make having much of an effect on the world around you. People like you different, your hair and eyes look different, and you're restricted from one or two spells; the only decisions that really matters are at the very end of the base game, and the expansion; which basically dictate one or two cinematics; in the expansion, you have three pairs of people you can kill one person each from, that's about it. The narrative however is quite good, and it appeals to the nature of a story that could quite go down as legend. You become a great hero in the span of years, and work to resolve your fate. The legendary items and gear make it feel more like an RPG, and the atmosphere is quite good. The only issue is, while great music, the lack of diversity in the music tracks makes some of the scenes rather... anticlimactic. When you're approaching the gates to armageddon basically, and the happy town music is playing.End result, for $10, and those qualities ascribed?Definitely a passing experience. Not excellent, but it's rather good.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												Hero, your health is low, do you have any potions or food?The beginning of an excellent series, worth at least a decent playthrough for the common RPG players. Fable: The Lost Chapters is an expansion, continuing where Fable left off. The expansion includes new land masses, new items, and new characters, as well as re-introducing characters from the earlier stages of the game. Fable: The Lost Chapters includes the original game, so there is no need to purchase Fable as a standalone. Fable Anniversary was released in the recent past, and is a revamp of everything including The Lost Chapters. Overall rating for Fable: The Lost Chapters; 9.5/10

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												The first game from Fable Franchise.Fable(or Fable the Lost Chapters) is a great RPG, especially if we consider it's launch date.Some features of this game are:+ A different level up system, you can only upgrade and get skills based on your play style, because doesn't make much sense play as a warrior and be able to upgrade your Mana or unlock some kind of "Meteor Storm".+ A karma system that gradually affects your appearance, it's pretty cool, if i can say so.+ An interesting customization system for it's time, today it must be a "little" outdated.+ A good variety of weapons and armor sets, even including some dresses, yes, you're male, but who cares? You'll look fabulous!+ Aging system, you'll get older, only up to 65, otherwise you would die from aging before you could finish the game.- The choices you make doesn't seems to make a big difference, if you kill an "important" NPC, it will never appears again, if you don't, it will never appears anyways.- Sometimes being bad is hard, since killing some of the most common enemies is considered a good deed.- Fable's economic system is faulty and as the way it works, it can be easily exploited.- Only you age up, you start as a kid, ends with 65, but almost everybody is still the same.- It's hard to use multiple skills, you can only use two at a time and then switch to other pair of skills, it's up to you, to organize and manage this.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												One of the best action RPG's around. I recommend this over Anniversary, the only thing changed is the art style and controller support, which I prefer the old graphics and I use a M+K perfectly fine so I don't see the need for a gamepad.  Played it countless times on the Original XBOX as a young boy so my Steam hours are not indicative to my hours in the game. I've probably done hundreds of playthroughs that's totalled up to hundreds of hours since I discovered it. Even though it's a decade old it still holds up. Magic is fun, melee combat is alright, as is the ranged. Upside to those two is that you can decapitate your foes and kick their heads around like soccer balls, though, so there's that. Humor is hit or miss a lot of times, but if you like Monty Python you'll probably like this. Some of the funniest scenes in the game come from the Book Collection quest, from when you scream "SH!T" at a classroom of children, to when you make a little kid perform a play about a vengeful cuckhold inn keeper. The quests are fun, and you can add challenges to them by boasting if you feel they're too easy. Story is a tried and true fantasy, "Only You Can Prevent Evil" trope with a flavor of "But Evil Can Be Cool Too" thrown in. Some quests in the game are strictly good or evil so there's room to roleplay there. It's usually really obvious as to what's what, too. Some of my fondest memories of RPG's are from the Fable series, and this game will always manage to keep  me interested even after years and years of knowing every inch of it. A sold 8/10 at least.  Maybe one day Fable 2 will be ported to PC and I can relive that again as well. It's nearly as good as its predecessor.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2012
												Fable is one of those classically good games with very nice production value. It's primarily an action RPG where you play as an epic hero as you quest through the lands. The game is full of humor and riddled with sidequests. But bare no bones about it, Fable is not a smart game by any stretch of the imagination. It's an action game first and an RPG second, and if you're determined enough you can beat the game without buying any equipment or levelling up your character in any way, I know this first hand.So don't go into this expecting a game with the intelligence of Baldur's Gate, or any of Molyneux's other games, because it's not. Thankfully, the PC port is pretty solid and it features a completely extended part of the game after the original's ending.Overall it's worth the 10$ on Steam and keeps your attention, but it's not anything to break an appointment over.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												The fable games have a truly unique feel to them, with a classic British Monty python esque sense of humour, and a generally laid back chill, cosy, warm, charming..atmosphere that I'm struggling to describe concisely. Fable: The lost chapters in my opinion is the best game of the series, a series which has sadly ended.The gameplay and controls are pleasingly simple, its not a game that will challenge your skill directly, but with things like the combat multiplier, quest boasting and mini-games allow you to test your skill and reap large rewards.You have various skills and abilities to unlock, and truly unique weapons, and armours to find in the world, each with a backstory. The world itself isn't open like Skyrim, its split into zones, all of which have their own feel and are well designed in that they feel just large enough to lose yourself in, and find new areas in places you thought you had explored.The story itself is like the gameplay simple, but in a good way. It is essentially a parody of your typical RPG tropes countering the typical "your parents were killed by bandits, and you are now the chosen one" origin story, with its distinct surreal humour, effectively delivered through amazing and memorable voice acting.The graphics are dated, but yet due to Fables art style still somehow seem just as relevant today as they did back when it came out. If however you do want a graphical improvement, you can get Fable: anniversary, however that is more expensive.Further info:-Combat multiplier is a combo that builds during combat, the less you're hit the higher it gets and the more XP you get.-Quest boasting is what it says on the tin, you pick up a quest and make a boast, for example you will do the quest naked etc, you gain extra gold and XP.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Many of you know me as Sinclair on steam, but closer friends & others know me as "That one kid that is crazy about writing dumb♥♥♥♥♥fictional stories".Let me tell you why.The first time I ever played this game was when I was 8 years old, It was my birthday and I've gotten a xbox classic from my parents. With the Console I obtained two free games, one of them was halo and the other one was this one.I hated the idea of halo (I was 8 ok) So I started playing Fable. It was the main reason why I grew up as a writer and I thank my creativity from this game.This game means a lot to me, not only because it was the one that got me into writing and videogames, but also because I've basically been playing it since today. I take breaks, of course, I finish playing it then i take a 2 year break and focus on other things, but its a great game to come back to. I honestly never grow tired of it.The OST is beautiful and fits the entire theme. You can be whoever you want to be in the game and the best thing is that you can kick a ♥♥♥♥ing chicken.It's a typical old school rpg game, and one of the best back then if you ask me. The writing and lore are absolutely stunning, the npc's are great and have a lot of backstory and the enemies are cool.You get a lot of choice within this game, something i've been missing from other fable games. Beside that, exploring is so much fun in this game. There is always something to do, and you always have quests. The main quest NEVER gets boring for me.The graphics are OK for its time, really, Beside that, I've heard they made a HD version of it too.I may be speaking out of nostalgia and love, but i honestly want everyone who likes old school RPG's to try this out. It has a typical "Epic" Hero theme and its just loveable. You get this feeling that you've been sucked into the game because of the story and end up playing it at 3 AM.9/10 !

content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Fable and I go way back. Back to the days of the original XBox. When Fable originally came out, I remember not knowing what it was all about exept for the little bit of hype overheard at Gamestop. And while the game may not have lived up to the biblical proportions of hype this game apparently recieved, it certainly resonated with me. Fable was one of the first games I remember playing for long, multiple hour sessions. This game had transended the medium and reached out of the television and captivated my attention in such a way that my free time was forfeit to it's greatness. That being said, it doesn't hold up so well. A lot of what made this game unique has been incorporated into games that followed it and has since been improved upon. Not to say there's nothing here to enjoy. Fable is a great action RPG with a great story, fun character progression and fun combat.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												It's a decent though albeit short RPG with a flexible leveling system, and a flexible alignment system to look good or evil. HOWEVER there are several downers that will prove annoying quickly.CONS1: The flexible leveling system causes your character to age quickly. This means that if you went and maxed out everything, your character turns from 18 to 65, which is not very fun for the gameplay perspective.2: The aging kills continuity, your character ages, but nobody else does. This means that your spouse(if you married) is suddenly younger than you because you went from 20 to 65.3: too many visual personal touches than are incorrectly modifying your alignment. Long hair should mean you become more attractive, and baldness a neutral or scary point.4: It's all too easy to skip something when it sets clicking to further the diologue.5: There's no controller setting, which is a downer since it could have been mapped or formatted to use a controller which is more ideal for RPGs than a keyboard and mouse.6: Certain story events force your character to change visuals suddenly(IE getting locked up in prison can get you shaved bald, and the one year passage on the ghost ship in the post game causes you to grow a beard and your hair is changed needlessly even if you have longer hair like the ponytail)7: difficulty decline. This issue is a pain for any RPG, and a killer of the fun factor. The endgame is supposed to have lengthy battles with insane damaging final bosses. Side quests tend to have an increasing difficulty that scales better than the final boss or bosses in game.PROs1: you can define your own sexuality freely. This means you can go around marrying or killing suitors as you please.2: the flexible leveling system lets you max out your offensive and defensive perks at your leisure, allowing you to max them all out to make the perfect character.3: Alignment is easy to adjust. If you focused on doing evil deeds and want to turn good, it's easy. If you went good and want to be evil, just kill a bunch of guards until you have had your fill of turning evil.4: Weapons are up to personal choice! As someone who loves swinging a sword, I like swinging a blade, it's more fun and more epic than lugging around a mace. 5: Customizable character visual. Tattoo vendors, barbers, armor and weapon vendors allow you to pick your ideal style(despite limitations).6: you're not obligated to level up to clear the game. This means you can stockpile experience in each of the 4 fields. You can max out your level, or you can go in with the bare essentials. The game world scales with your level to things don't remain impossible.7: FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE CONTROLS! This is a major PRO for this game! Mapping which keys or buttons the way you want to what functions(Though unfortunately you can't map controls to a USB controller), so a user cam simplify or complicate controls to their liking if certain functions are allowed to share buttons or keys.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												If you enjoy having a saying on what will happen and not just being the blind guy who receives orders and has to deal with the consequences without having a choice, this game is for you. To put it simply: this game is awesome.When I watched the trailer I was like "Meh. Might aswell read the reviews." and the reviews made me wonder "If it's such a good game, why does the trailer suck?". So I decided to watch some gameplay. The best advice I can give you is: Watch the gameplay of the first mission. By then you'll problably know wether you'll like it or not.As for me? I loved this game. I've spent too many months playing FPS games and this game made me remember why I love RPGs so much.At this current time I finished the game as a good guy, and I have 26 hours of playing it. I haven't even gotten into the assassin aspect of the game, the thieving and all those stuff which cause you to be evil. I've still got to play the evil side of the coin and see what kind of stuff will happen differently. Also, there is much I haven't done yet, side quests and things of the sort.Also, the combat is awesome. While you might choose to be the overpowered dude who beats everyone up, you also can choose to play not to your fullest power, but actually use one or two magics at a time. If you play the overpowered dude, combat gets boring too quickly, since no foe will stand up to your power. But if you decide to give your opponents a fair fight, the combat is really interesting. The enemies don't have much power by themselves, but they certainly beat you in numbers and I found myself dying a few times. But don't worry about it, the game is really fair and it gives you a nice ammount of revives with the ability of you being able to buy more revives really cheap once you get to the mid point of the game (before that they're there, but they aren't that cheap in comparison to the gold you have).To sum up: This is a must-have. If it is in sale, you should buy it ASAP. If it's not, you should take a look at the cost and see if it's worth it. But even at it's full price, in my opinion it's worth it.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												First off, this might sound a bit biased. That's because it absolutely is.I grew up playing this game on my old Xbox. My mom would tell me "[redacted], you can play this game, but only if you're a good guy". I would run around, only killing evil things, eventually becoming a shining beacon of happiness and hope throughout Albion.Then I turned 10. Things got a bit crazy. May or may not have "accidently" slaughtered a couple villages and grew a set of horns.Anyway.That was in the past.I hadn't played this game in at least 7 years (which is crazy to think about) and for some reason, never checked on Steam for it. When I saw it at the Summer Sale, I froze. Oh my god. It's my game. I picked it up without thinking about it, and am 100% happy with my decision.The game is great. The voice acting is horrible. The faces and lip movements are really bad. The Guildmaster is annoying as hell. But the game is a rare gem from the past that I don't think anyone should miss playing.This is the Lost Chapters. It adds much, much more to the base game. It no longer ends when you beat the main villain the first time. Instead, you find yourself with another HALF A GAME to go. More weapons, more enemies, more armor, more quests, and more fun.It also runs really, really well on my laptop. I still haven't felt it get hot, even after a 5-hour gaming session. Camera is a bit wonky, and I had to rebind a few keys (who would want to block with the middle mouse?). Once I got used to it, I've done very well with it.One thing I love about this game, is that it can give you a sense of being overpowered, but only if you play it well. If you mess up, you can easily be overwhelmed by enemies and lose half your health. Play it right, and the only damage you'll take is from a few stray crossbow bolts. If you like rpg games, this game is one of the best out there, even today. I highly, highly, highly recommend getting it and trying it out. After you endure the first hour or so of not-so-great "gameplay", you'll come to love this game as much as I do.Well, not as much.Not nearly.

												Ok, It's Fable... We have mostly played it before. I picked this up simply to scratch a nostalgia itch. On the whole I found that it was good... still! Yes there are a couple of issues as it's an older game so the port hasn't aged particuly well, no controller support and as the magic system relied on three buttons on the xbox version it now relies on 2 (left and right mouse) which can make it a little difficult with all the scrolling to find the apropriate spell. you could of course get very wow style and have a million hotkeys buuut meh, its not really designed around it.Anyway back on track, the port is actually good, 1080 supported (which looks quite lovely!)  AA is supported as well as some basic visual sliders and such. The only thing i found didnt work properly was the refresh rate, is seem to stick at 60fps, not terrible at all but i have a 120hz monitor sooo, well it would have been nice.On to gameplay! Yes the game is flawed... it does feel a little like "babby's first RPG"  but it has bags of character and you will remember your time with it. i found on my recent playthrough some more annoyances... such as indestructible barrels, having to run MILES to pick up rent and a slightly janky inventory. Seriously when you pick up a book you cant find it in your inventory.... its in your hero's logbook UNLESS it is a note/letter given by a non main story NPC and then it turns up in the "other" section of you inventory.  Yes the attack cycles will get repetative you will get bores of the 4 or 5 different unblockable "flourish" moves, ranged combat feels slow and you become super powerful very quickly. and then you feel like all the experience you have aquired is useless (it is) But with all that being said, Albion is a fantastic world to inhabit, a lot of thought went in to contextualising the world, everybody has a life that you can see being lead, they will react accordingly... if you raid Oakvale, and murder people (even as a good guy) you will find that for some time the inhabitants will cower and run away from you... even though you have a halo....THE BOTTOM LINE.....Flawed, but fun and a relatively well done and useable port

Posted: October 22, 2012
												Fable: The Lost Chapter was not only my first RPG, growing up it was the game I'd always go back to after dipping into games that just couldn't compare to the truly epic experiences I'd have with it. The world and lore of Albion flowed through my mind like the blood in my veins. It was like a second home to me. And after dipping into it for the first time in years, I found that it still is.     I always find that I keep critique to a minimum when it comes to Fable: The Lost Chapters. I do this intentionally. This game was my childhood. I therefore don't want to destroy the fond memories I have of it by locating negative aspects with it.      I'm really not sure if you'll have such a great experience I've had and still have with this game, but I really want to believe that you will. Posted: January 5, 2014
												Fable: The Lost Chapters builds upon the original best-selling Fable with loads of new content including new regions, quests and enhanced story elements that further enhance the mystical world of Albion. Fable: The Lost Chapters gives players the chance to fight new monsters, use epic spells to obliterate huge numbers of enemies, don new armor, wield additional weapons and interact with friends and foes using amazing new expressions.In this role-playing adventure game from Lionhead Studios, every action determines a character’s skills, appearance and morality. A character’s life story is created from childhood through adulthood and on to old age. As additional story and side quests await, so too does the path of righteousness, as well as the life of evil. With every choice, a character transforms into a reflection of his actions and decisions.

Compared to the other games in the Fable franchise this is gold and the others are dog♥♥♥♥♥♥ In Fable you get loads of moral choices which affect your character and the way other people in the world views you. But the main part of the game is the amazing story and the great side-quests and the choices you have to make, there's load of things to do! (Unless you just rush the main quest which I don't suggest) Only problem I have is that the difficulty is really easy, and completing the game without ever dying isn't hard. This game is an absolutely buy! You'll have hours of fun, and seeing at it is quite a old game, it's quite cheap as well!

However, the control system and game mechanics are quite dated now, and I found getting around, fighting and working through puzzles more than a little frustrating. Posted: December 27, 2013
												My favorite game of all time! Deep and involving story that goes beyond just the main quest that can be read about in the huge array of books scattered throughout Albion. The loading times on PC are only 3-4 seconds long, vs the Xbox's time (15-20 secs).The huge amount of weapons and armours are fantastically designed and each have a unique ability. The amount of choice is amazing! You can marry a man or a woman, you can be good or evil, be a powerful wizard or a brutal fighter. There are so many choices and paths to take! The open world environment allows you to roam free between towns and find ancient legendary weapons hidden long ago in chests and behind magic stone gates known as Demon Doors, which to open, you must solve a riddle or complete a challenge. The best game I've ever played, and a long time favorite! This game is a must-own for every roleplayer out there.EDIT: It's been a couple of years since I wrote this review and this game continues to be one of my favorites in my steam library. It's fair to say that I won't ever stop playing this game.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Let me start off by saying one thing. This is hands down the best game that has ever been made. There is no contest and there will never be another game that is as good as Fable. I may be a little biased because this game has been with me since the original XBOX came out, but I think I'm justified. I remember it vividly: my small six-year-old self pressing buttons, enjoying the incredible gameplay, et cetera. It never does get old. I replay this game often and it's the same effect every time. Now that I'm grown the effect is a little different, mind you. I start up the game and I seem to ejaculate pretty much everything I have in me because this game is just perfect. It's just so perfect every single time. I don't care if the graphics are dated. I don't care if it's not popular. I don't care if the audio quality is like filtering diarrhea through a tube sock. This is simply the best game that has ever been made. If you don't have this game in your library then you're not alive. You haven't lived yet. Just do it. Just buy this game and stop reading my dumbass emotional review. Now I'm crying. Look what you've done to me.Thank you merciful Molyneux.

Posted: May 11, 2013
												This is the game that takes the title as I favourite RPG ever. It may not have the size and content of Skyrim, but the impacts you make on the world really add to the immersion. People actually chanting your name and either cowering from you or praising you, and actually knowing when or when not to oppose you is something that even Skyrim fails to achieve. The combat may seem just like a button masher but if you know what your doing, you can turn it into a fun game of mind tricks with your opponents. The story is the cherry on top of this brilliant cake, and contrary to what many people say, the game can get pretty difficult.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												First off, this might sound a bit biased. That's because it absolutely is.I grew up playing this game on my old Xbox. My mom would tell me "[redacted], you can play this game, but only if you're a good guy". I would run around, only killing evil things, eventually becoming a shining beacon of happiness and hope throughout Albion.Then I turned 10. Things got a bit crazy. May or may not have "accidently" slaughtered a couple villages and grew a set of horns.Anyway.That was in the past.I hadn't played this game in at least 7 years (which is crazy to think about) and for some reason, never checked on Steam for it. When I saw it at the Summer Sale, I froze. Oh my god. It's my game. I picked it up without thinking about it, and am 100% happy with my decision.The game is great. The voice acting is horrible. The faces and lip movements are really bad. The Guildmaster is annoying as hell. But the game is a rare gem from the past that I don't think anyone should miss playing.This is the Lost Chapters. It adds much, much more to the base game. It no longer ends when you beat the main villain the first time. Instead, you find yourself with another HALF A GAME to go. More weapons, more enemies, more armor, more quests, and more fun.It also runs really, really well on my laptop. I still haven't felt it get hot, even after a 5-hour gaming session. Camera is a bit wonky, and I had to rebind a few keys (who would want to block with the middle mouse?). Once I got used to it, I've done very well with it.One thing I love about this game, is that it can give you a sense of being overpowered, but only if you play it well. If you mess up, you can easily be overwhelmed by enemies and lose half your health. Play it right, and the only damage you'll take is from a few stray crossbow bolts. If you like rpg games, this game is one of the best out there, even today. I highly, highly, highly recommend getting it and trying it out. After you endure the first hour or so of not-so-great "gameplay", you'll come to love this game as much as I do.Well, not as much.Not nearly.

This is a time classic game where the graphics aged well and the game play still within reach of the modern gamer. It is one of the all time best single player RPG games and story lines for that matter. Posted: February 27, 2014
												As of having over 200+ Hours on the original released on the xbox, I have a deep love for this great rpg, set in one of the best fantasy worlds known as albion, which is widely known and loved my many. With the visuals overly improved due to more computing power from home pc's, I finally got to emerse myself in this amazing world once more, with new quests and other features that the original fable did not possess. Lost chapters how ever let me 1 or half a night to complete even though you could play it for hours on end, and not get bored with its charms. Posted: February 1, 2015
												The only GOOD Fable game for PC, Fable: The Lost Chapters. It is the only Fable game for PC worth buying and playing. The world of Albion feels alive and beautiful, full of secrets and legend. The landscapes are very well detailed and nicely put together, and the graphics still hold up quite decently despite its age. The soundtrack is incredible, and the voice acting is all quite enjoyable. There's tons and tons to do in this game, and even when you beat it, can continue to play after the endgame is complete (You just have to wait patiently through the credits without skipping them). Save your money, don't buy Fable Anniversary, buy THIS GAME instead. They are LITERALLY the exact same game, only this one wasn't horribly maimed and twisted into a piece of garbage.

												Finally finished this game. If you haven't yet, do so. It's a great fantasy roleplaying game that might be a little easy. Posted: July 5, 2014
												Fable is one of my favourite games on the original XBOX. A solid 15-20 hours of pure fun gameplay. Fable to this day holds a spot as one of my favorite adventure RPG games. Everything about this game is right. For the time it was released it had so many innovative ideas. Your character actually got scarred up and caried your wounds from battle with you throughout the game. You could become good or evil with a noticeable difference to your characters appearance to show this. The world is beautiful, happy and great fun to adventure through. The only downfall with this game is it's short time. If you have never played Fable before I can't reccomend this enough as I feel everyone should play through this game at least once.

Posted: February 7, 2014
												Fable - The Lost Chapters, a classic game that originally released in October of 2005 on the original Xbox, September of the same year on PC, ported to Steam in December 2011 and recently had an HD re-release on Xbox 360. Fable is a RPG in which your decisions dictate where the story will go. You can be a Hero of purity and good or a Hero of deceit and evil. This was a groundbreaking feature when it first released because no other game on the market had that "I really control this character's life" feel to it. With a unique skill leveling system, you can make yourself a burly warrior, a gifted mage, a craft thief, or as I like to do, a "Jack-of-All-Trades" sort of build.When the game begins, you are still just a boy in the town of Oakvale. It's your sister's birthday and you need to find her a present. Your choices start at a young age, as you decide where you want to do good or bad deeds to make the few gold needed to get the gift. Shortly after you get the gift, bandits raid your little town and slaughter everyone. You're saved by a member of The Heroes Guild and taken there where you'll grow up and learn to be a Hero. Will you be The Hero of Avo or a Servant of Skorn. The choice is yours.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												Fable:The Lost Chapters is an amazing game as it adds to the original fable game.You can be as evil as satan himself or a hero that mankind needs.Although the game gets easy if you know what you're doing,I still find it enjoyable.The Lost Chapters gave me a reason to play this amazing game all over again and I give it a 9/10.

Posted: March 27, 2012
												Fable takes the old cliche boy turned Hero story and makes it a very thorough and engaging game story-- Fleshed out in such a way it goes beyond the cliche completely. It remains so unique you probably won't put this down even after you've beaten it a couple times. Replayability is insane. If you're like most of my friends and have only played the sequels, you're really missing out. The first in the series is the best, and definitely one of my favourite games.The RPG mechanics are easily exploitable, but if you play the game straight as it's intended, it's a Hell of a lot of fun.Your character changes based on your actions and your skills.If you decide to get buff and put points into strength, your character visibly gets more muscle definition.If you invest in learning magics, runes and symbols will start glowing on your body.The people around you react to your actions and appearance, running from you or following you around and singing your praise, possibly even falling in love with you.Maybe the game has really bad voice acting, maybe its character morphing system forgets a value sometimes and glitches out so you look funny (Also causes the AI to act conflicted sometimes -hilariously enough- screaming in fear but madly in love with you).Sure, it has a really bad, really long tutorial.There are some tone inconsistencies in the late game that don't really flow with the initial non-TLC ending, and small issues with age show.But that's all trying really hard to find issues with it.This is definitely the best RPG of its time.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												This game really shows why the Fable series has been such a huge hit for all these years. The newest ones are only going to get better. It's so great to see how one of the greatest franchises began. Some people might think this particular game is no different than a free-to-play fantasy rpg, but show me a free-to-play that has this much of a diverse storyline. The actions you choose change the world around you. You are in ultimate control over what happens, so playing this game all the way through more than once will be far from boring. Even after this game goes off-sale it's still worth the $10. Do yourself a favor and buy this game. Don't put it on your wishlist. It's too good to wait for someone to buy it for you. Get it now and truly feel what it means to be in control of your own destiny.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game was amazing when it came out, and it's still amazing to this day.The story holds up, the combat holds up, the mechanics hold up. Hey, even the graphics hold up well enough.If you've never played this, I cannot recommend it enough. If you've played Fable III and not this one, boy, you're in for a treat.It really is a shame Fable II is never coming to PC, it's the only other game in the franchise that can compete with the first in my opinion, despite all the fuss about firearms being in it.Bottom line, if never played it before and want a great, fresh, medieval fantasy game experience, this is where you should look. If you've played it once or twice before, it's a game with enough choices to revisit once more. If you already played it thoroughly and like it, I'm sure I don't even have to tell you to play it all over again sometime.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Fable TLC is great for people who don't have an original copy of either Fable or Fable TLC for the original Xbox. The game is a direct port and I experienced no bugs or crashing when I played. One thing that players should keep in mind when purchasing this game is that there is no controller support for the game. Playing on the keyboard was incredibly difficult for me because I was so used to the Xbox controller format. To fix this I used Xpadder and made a specific profile that worked very well with the game. I've probably beaten this game about 6 or 7 times and it never gets old. It's a classic game and worth shelling out the cash to play it.
