Posted: September 21, 2014
												With the heightened awareness of this due to Anniversary's release, I guess I'll give my opinion of this:Pretty sweet.Combat is pretty easy, but not quite as easy as Fable 2 and 3. If you dont buy Ressurectional Phails and dont wear Armour and don't put any points into the defensive skills, you end up with ♥♥♥♥ing hard combat though. Basically go full YOLO and ♥♥♥♥ defenses if you want to have to actually think in combat.That being said, there are a few gamebreakers. Basically the physical shield spell. With maxed mana pool that spell becomes basically god mode. I'd suggest not using it.Besides that, you have pretty basic combat: Range, Melee and Magic weapons/spells are all availiable for use at any time, similar to Kingdoms of Amalur (except Amalur's skill and combat system is superior in every way and you should be playing Amalur as it is basically Fable 1 but will less herp derp and more polish.). This allows you to use all of your weapons and spells without constantly go through menus and such. Overall pretty sweet.The game itself has charm in both its age, its somewhat unusual aesthetics, and probably a bit of nostalgia too. Going evil is especially funny as you just become more cartoon villian than anything. Even slaughtering an entire town doesnt feel like it has any real rammifactions, which is hilarious in its own right. It eventually comes down to standing in the middle of Oakvale with a badass sword killing an endless stream of guards before getting bored, sheathing your weapon and leaving to the adjacent town, who doesnt recognise nor care that you just killed like 100 dudes.There are downsides though: Spellcasting is based heavily on the system introduced for the Xbox, that is, only having a limited number of buttons compared to the larger number of spells. Get used to scrolling through pairs of owned spells. At the very least the game has the courtesy to let you organise these pairs. I cant remember if you can use the number keys for spells, you might - but don't take my lack of a conclusive answer sway you towards the 'it does'. Additionally the spells themselves are pretty hit and miss. Lightning is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max rank it and then you become the ♥♥♥♥ing god of lightning. Fireball is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max it, and you stand around charging it up to max damage while hoping you dont get interupted - that is to say, you will. Divine power/Infernal fury (or whatever thier names were) are OP as hell and basically become the only offensive spell worth noting at high level, even if it has a huge charge time. Slow time is godly. Heal is useless because healing potions do more, dont cost mana, and dont waste skill points.I could continue, but you get the idea. You quickly realise that some of the spells are useful, others simply aren't. There is some degree of replayability in terms of going range/mage/melee or any mix of those (Multi-strike and Multi-arrow do exactly what they say and are really nice for Mage/melee and Mage/range hybrid playthroughs.) however the story itself isn't all that good for replayability, and the limited map space again limits it. Didn't stop me as a kid from playing this WAY too much though.Basically, it's a fun 'old' (depends on your definition of old I guess, but by modern standards I'd call it fairly old - definately not oldschool though. DEFINATELY NOT) RPG that is worth a shot for its pretty low cost.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												 I have to say I wasn't to exited to play this game when I first started. I previously played Fable III and only bought the game after hearing the poplar complaint that Fable II and III had failed to live up standards of the first game. Firstly,  the opening tutorial was painful at times and the graphics are not the best thing this game has to offer, but once you get past that, Fable: The Lost Chapters is a truly enjoyable game. The combat system is fluid for melee, ranged, and magic alike, the leveling/experience system rewards you XP for not only defeating monsters and completing quest but also for which skills you used to do so. For explain, if I used magic abilities, whether they be combative or not, I would receive Magic XP, which I then could spend on buying or upgrading my magical talents.  Thus the more I use my skills, the better I will be at those skills. Another feature I liked was the ability to Boast. Just after you take a quest you have the ability to Boast about what you will do on said quest, for explain doing the entire quest with no clothes or without taking or doing damage, doing so increases gold you will receive at the completion of the quest while also providing a challenge for the journey ahead.  In order to truly get the Fable experience and better understand the series you must give this game a try.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												With the heightened awareness of this due to Anniversary's release, I guess I'll give my opinion of this:Pretty sweet.Combat is pretty easy, but not quite as easy as Fable 2 and 3. If you dont buy Ressurectional Phails and dont wear Armour and don't put any points into the defensive skills, you end up with ♥♥♥♥ing hard combat though. Basically go full YOLO and ♥♥♥♥ defenses if you want to have to actually think in combat.That being said, there are a few gamebreakers. Basically the physical shield spell. With maxed mana pool that spell becomes basically god mode. I'd suggest not using it.Besides that, you have pretty basic combat: Range, Melee and Magic weapons/spells are all availiable for use at any time, similar to Kingdoms of Amalur (except Amalur's skill and combat system is superior in every way and you should be playing Amalur as it is basically Fable 1 but will less herp derp and more polish.). This allows you to use all of your weapons and spells without constantly go through menus and such. Overall pretty sweet.The game itself has charm in both its age, its somewhat unusual aesthetics, and probably a bit of nostalgia too. Going evil is especially funny as you just become more cartoon villian than anything. Even slaughtering an entire town doesnt feel like it has any real rammifactions, which is hilarious in its own right. It eventually comes down to standing in the middle of Oakvale with a badass sword killing an endless stream of guards before getting bored, sheathing your weapon and leaving to the adjacent town, who doesnt recognise nor care that you just killed like 100 dudes.There are downsides though: Spellcasting is based heavily on the system introduced for the Xbox, that is, only having a limited number of buttons compared to the larger number of spells. Get used to scrolling through pairs of owned spells. At the very least the game has the courtesy to let you organise these pairs. I cant remember if you can use the number keys for spells, you might - but don't take my lack of a conclusive answer sway you towards the 'it does'. Additionally the spells themselves are pretty hit and miss. Lightning is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max rank it and then you become the ♥♥♥♥ing god of lightning. Fireball is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max it, and you stand around charging it up to max damage while hoping you dont get interupted - that is to say, you will. Divine power/Infernal fury (or whatever thier names were) are OP as hell and basically become the only offensive spell worth noting at high level, even if it has a huge charge time. Slow time is godly. Heal is useless because healing potions do more, dont cost mana, and dont waste skill points.I could continue, but you get the idea. You quickly realise that some of the spells are useful, others simply aren't. There is some degree of replayability in terms of going range/mage/melee or any mix of those (Multi-strike and Multi-arrow do exactly what they say and are really nice for Mage/melee and Mage/range hybrid playthroughs.) however the story itself isn't all that good for replayability, and the limited map space again limits it. Didn't stop me as a kid from playing this WAY too much though.Basically, it's a fun 'old' (depends on your definition of old I guess, but by modern standards I'd call it fairly old - definately not oldschool though. DEFINATELY NOT) RPG that is worth a shot for its pretty low cost.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												Fable is a game I've played several times, and at first I thought it was fantastic. I loved the story, the world, and it was really one of the first RPG's I really got into. I owned it on Xbox, and after losing it I thought I'd buy it again on steam. And after playing and beating Fable for the hundredth time, I've only just now began to realize this game is far from perfect.Don't get me wrong, Fable is still a good game, and decent RPG overall. The graphics hold up pretty well today, which is impressive for a game that's going on 12 years old. But that's really where Fable ends, "Good" and "Decent" The story has really weird pacing, the game's length is far from impressive, and the games lack of side quests really detract from replay value. Another thing I've come to dislike about fable is how simple it is. The game has very few deep and interesting mechanics, and some of the ones that are there are broken (ex. the morality and ageing systems)It may seem like I'm harping on it, but I would still recommend Fable to both casual gamers, and fans of action RPGs. While it may seem lack luster, Fable is still a solid experience with great combat, good characters, an interesting world to explore, and plenty of chickens to kick. It was a fantastic third person action RPG experience back in 2004, and while it has aged over the years, I think Falble is a purchase that you won't regret.

Posted: September 4, 2014
												I've played Fable in so many ways over so, so many years. I was one of the poor fools waiting years for it to come out, and event hen I was kinda late to the party. All you really need to know is that this game -should- be awful. It failed the hype more than any other game in the history of ever (except maaaybe Duke Nukem Forever, because that one is awful), the graphics were not what they could have been, the combat shouldn't be fun, the voice acting is painful, the story is simplistic, and a few of the design decisions for models still hurt my brain.But the game is wonderful. For all that is 'missing', your mind is happy to fill it in, for all that combat should be a boring slog, every player will try a handful of weird rules and challenges, or, just goof off entirely, and get their fun. Collectibles are at once plentiful, and achievable without aid. Marriage is utterly pointless and unfulfilling. . .that's it, marriage is just pointless and unfulfilling. >.> Meta humor >.> Point is, there is no reason this game should be so awesome, and that's why it stands out as the shining beacon of "See here! This is what matters!" - Aesthetics. Every individual piece seems mismatched, disjointed, and frankly lacklustre on its own. Put them together and. . .you know the rest. Personally, I find this games sits with precious few others on that point of pure aesthetic gold, and among western-produced RPGs? It almost stands alone. Backing away from cartoonishness severely damaged the franchise, and I really do place 90% of the blame on that alone. I'm serious. If they remade Fable III, the exact game, but with Fable's graphics (and more important, use of graphics)? It'd be fine. Tho the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥map, weird hero retreat thing, and those damned guild seals to unlock chests vs. the old xp system would still be huge marrs, I think we could forgive a lot more if the game had just been charming. I'm buying Anniversary because I have to see it first hand. . . but looking at the screenshots honestly reminds me of when I heard the interview about how they finally had the tech to render lifelike creations in Phantom Menace, and used that to make Jar Jar Binks. . . . . What you do with what you got matters a helluva lot more . .tho I never liked Star Wars as a franchise because it's aesthetic has never appealed to me (too much metal >.>), and all it has to offer is the EXACT Hero's Journey, in space, with Buddhism. No thanks. I'll go read Saiyuki.

												Best game EVAR!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! even tho its still the first ever fable its on eof the best... there is sooooo many choises you have to make all the time. It is one of the true RPG'S that i have ever played. unlike the elder scrolls (which i love btw) there is more choices then if you kill the dark brotherhood or join the imperials or the stormcloaks in skyrim but there is many more that can change who you are as a person in the game. Even how you look in public ( so what you wear how your hairstile is ) efects how people see you. if you become a very evil person you start to have people think you dark and demnic and only those type of people will like you and would like to marry you ( which you can also do in the game) and you also start to grow horns out of the top of your head. and if your a really good person you have a halo on the top of your head floating and the general amount of people will clap for you and cheer and all that when you enter towns and villages. There are many side quests to that you can find on the guild table like defend this farm or defeat this boss and help the traders find they're camp. some quests contradict (hopefully i spelt it right ) eachother like if your defending the farm, there could be a quest saying that the bandits who are attacking the farm need your help to get the supplies, Again, depending on who you are in the game you can choose what you want to do. YOU MISSED OUT!Despite its two let-down sequels, this game is absolutley adoreable and one of the best fantasy games i ever had the pleasure to play 3 times completly through the story and all the sidequests.That being said and being outed as a fanboy, you got to be a person that likes story and the apsect of choosing between bad and good. The fighting system isn't actually that good, but the world the game manages to create around you just pulls you in and spits you out hours of hours of hours of hourrs later with a smile on your face. Every thing you do shapes (literally) your character, some examples:Learn more spells and runes will slowly appear on your skin.Do a lot of mean stuff, your skin will start to decay.Use a lot of heavy weapons, your body will become more muscular.Buy whole villages, get rich, get married.People will react to you based on what you have done in the past.The whole freakin' package of what you would love in terms of character development.One more thing: The Lost Chapters, originally an addon (but only version on steam by now) feels a bit forcefully attached to the game, which is pretty much what happend, but it gives some more gameplay and new areas, so, well, thats still fine i guess^^ And it doens't hurt the overall impression the game makes.In my opinion you haven't played a good fantasy story yet, if you haven't played this game.

												Fable - The Lost Chapters is a game bases on a small kid that lives in the town of oakvale one night his town gets attacked by bandits and he tries to flee but sadly see his parents die before his own eyes he then wants revenge and joins the hero's guild I quite enjoyed the game,once you start playing you just need to keep going,it's like a good book! the story isn't the strongest part of this game although i quite liked it.The game is now 8 years old and the graphics do show that a bit but there are worse looking games the graphics are very colorfull though and the big magic attacks look pretty good,also it means that this game runs great on old systems my pc has a gt 545 and it can run this game on maximum like a breeze There is a decent amount of choice in weapons although the blades and maces are way better then the bows and crossbowsthere also is a nice amount of armour sets to choose from but i do think that the ''magic'' combat needs a bit more attention.attack and armour wise.This games is also pretty short (played it out in around 12 hours) but you can keep playing a new secondary story after you defeat the final boss,but i dont think that will take to long also there are a couple of things that to bother me in this game1.theres a glitch/exploit how you can get unlimited money so basicly you can beat the game without taking a potion or anything 2.the mouth anymations are really really bad.3.The game world is a bit small,and there are a bunch of loading screens,they don't take very long so it isn't a big complaint.If you can pick this game up for cheap i would reccomend it,especially for those who like rpg's and fantasy games. i would give it a (6/10)

Posted: January 28, 2015
												This is by far the best fantasy RPG I've ever played. Charming, classic, and crisp, it delivers a neat story, an engrossing world, a well developed form of real time gameplay that is easy to learn but hard to master, an immaculate sense of freedom, loads of replayability, and just the right amount of wit and humor to hold it all together. While the graphics pale in comparison to that of modern games, they are nevertheless from an era when 3D, though it had been in fairly common use for some ten years or so already, was finally actually starting to look good, and thus to my eyes this game looks all the more amazing. I would definitely recommend this version over the abomindable cash grab that is Fable Anniversary (which is exactly the same game as TLC but is $25 more simply because it looks prettier). Just don't be suprised if you end up playing it for 12 hours in one sitting on your very first go.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												If you are new to RPGs this is a good game to cut your teeth on.First off, I am relatively new to the pick and choose RPG. That said, this was the first one I ever played. Although the graphics look a little dated, it still was a fantastic game that had a good plot. Mind you this game came out before game makers incuded voice acting for the main characters. So your character is silent for most of the dialogue. The game is a pretty quick one and has a decent amount of content and replay value. An enjoyable feature was that you could take parts of all classes and include them in your game for example, you could be a tank that shoots lightning, and then pull out your bow to fight. In the end, I played it through twice, had a good bit of fun both ways. Really got a good kick out of some of the British humor... (Loads of it)If you want an example, just look at the Union Jack boxers the character sports when he doesnt wear his armor....

Posted: August 31, 2014
												One of the best RPGs of the decade. Simple, yet beautiful. Fable's trademark is the fight between good and evil and the freedom that you, as the main hero, have to choose your own side. You can be evil from start to finish and literaly end the story in tragedy, instead of saving the world for selfish purposes, as it usualy is when you take an evil path in a RPG that has a happy ending regardless of your choices. Beign good, as always, also has its advantages and can be rewarding and fun. You'll feel like finishing the game more than once just to see the differences between playing the good and the bad guy. I've been playing and replaying this game throughout the years and it never gets old.Graphics, animations, gameplay and soundtrack still holds up, nothing feels dated or inadequade, even though the game is already ten years old. If you like action-centered RPGs, this one is for you.Gameplay - 8/10Soundtrack - 8/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 6/10Challenge Level - 3/10Replayability - 4/10

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Hra, kterou jsem na prvních pár pokusů nedohrál. Snažil sem se co nejrychleji doběhnout hlavní lini, samozřejmě vedlejší úkoly sem také bral, ale vždycky ve třech čtvrtinách mě hra z nějakého důvodu přestala bavit. Jednoho dne, po asi 20. rozehrání sem si řekl kurňa, tak já teda zkusim koupit barák, udělat manželku, zahrát si hospodský hry, měnit účesy,... A zjistil jsem, že Fable je ještě větší hra, než sem myslel. A to sem si původně myslel, že je pěkně malá, díky ne tak rozlehlým lokacím. Úplně jsem zapoměl na hlavní příběh a užíval si vítězství v hospodách, soutěžích v kopání slepic, sbírání legendárních zbraní, rybaření, hledání pokladů, atd. Hra je na tom jako Morrowind/Oblivion. Musíte mít chuť si jí užít. Osobně jediný zápor, který mi vadil, je ten, že i když už je hrdina v pokročilém věku, lidé na něj pořád mluví jako na fakana a ťuťu ňuňu, no musíš zabít balveriny, kteří trhají vesničany na kousky, yes you do, oh yes you do... Kromě toho nemám námitek.Pro: Pěkné lokace, pěkně vypadající zbraně a brnění, magie, minihry, vedlejší možnosti, zpodobení dobra a zla, místy humorProti: Malé lokace, mluva vesničanů, ne moc kvalitní příběh

Posted: January 17, 2012
												Greatest game of all time.  If you haven't played it yet, PLAY IT.  A lot of my love for this game may be nostalgia, but overall it is an extremely solid game.  There are secrets to uncover, the gameplay is fun, the story is interesting but succinct, and the universe is very unique.  You will not get an insane amount of game time out of the main storyline, but there are plenty of side missions and funny things you can do that will keep you occupied for a while.  Some people think that games like this are too old-fashioned since they don't offer a truly open-world environment, but I personally prefer linearity.  I would take this over Skyrim any day.  The only qualm I have with this game is that it is a bit too easy - if it had a higher difficulty setting, I would have no need to ever purchase another game.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												What can I say, utterly brilliant apart from some niggling flaws.  Graphically: Dated obviously, but the art direction is so good that it doesn't matter.  It looks lush.Combat: A bit too much stun locking from certain mobs, dodging is not well implemented.  Mostly good though.Combat styles: There's lots of variety, go the caster path, the ranged path or the tank path.  They all work and there's room for variety within those styles as well.Story: Excellent, beautifully scripted, brilliantly voiced.The World:  Here is where this game excels.  It's vibrant, funny and interesting.  In no other game, other than maybe other Fable games, is it such fun to just wander round listening to the splendidly insane chatter.  There is just an incredible amount of superb voice acting, often for purely throwaway world detail. Silly side quests like the books for school kids are just perfectly done and just add to the overall entertainment.  The depth of the interactions is sometimes just amazing, one minor niggle is that many of these interactions are only available to naughty people.  The good guys don't get to poke around in the game mechanics so much.  Save System: God awful, mental.  Why?  I guess it works well enough once you are used to it, but it is certainly strange.One of the greatest games ever, full to bursting with charm, cleverness and wit.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												So please ignore the amount of hours I have played because I actually already completed this Game 2 times one on my original Xbox and then I replayed it after playing Fable 2 on my 360 so I’m just starting my 3rd run and Oh boy am I excited!In a world were your choices define the world around you, how others perceive you and even how you looks change based on how you play you will make a perils journey of growing up from a Small boy into a young man after your family are killed and you must embark on journey of Revenge in a Rich Fantasy world laced with heaps of comedy.So off you go thundering around the Kingdom of Albion kicking every Chicken in sight and farting on any man, woman or child dumb enough to allow you near them.The one thing that always amazed me about this game and it still rings true today is how much fun can be had from being "BAD" you wonder into a village you have terrorised them and then the people cower in fear and scream for there lives at the mere sight of you.The same with being "GOOD" people will praise you and sometimes even cheer in the great heroes presence....and trust me I know this just a game but its really really cool.In fable - The Lost Chapters you will laugh you will cry and I'm sure you will most likely die from time to time too.This is game is a Classic Among classics and is worth every penny of the £6.99 price tag.8/10An absolute must for any self respecting RPG lover.

Posted: October 10, 2015
												Played this game a lot on the old Xbox, and got this for nostalgia's sake just recently, and I'd have to say that it still holds up pretty well.  Sure, Fable has problems. It was not the game that was promised, and some of the respawns between maps are irritating in the extreme... but there's a lot of good old-school action-adventure stuff in here.Three hours into the Steam version, and I've had no crashes or save/load problems (there were a few with the Xbox version) and I've not noticed any annoying glitches yet. If you enjoyed the original on Xbox and are thinking about this one, I can recommend it.  If you're just looking for a casual RPG/Adventure/Combat game and don't mind the dated (but still quite nice) graphics, then I'd also recommend it.This is a love-it or hate-it game, with its roots firmly back in the days when they didn't make such games too easy. Think of it as a bit like Overlord (without the minions) and you might be on more-or-less the right track.

Posted: September 25, 2014
												I played this game a long time ago, and I remember having a lot of fun.So nostalgically recalling all the good times I had, I recently purchased the original Fable to play, hoping to recreate the experience.Sadly, I must report that I was severely disappointed. The game is just so outdated, I can't play for five minutes straight without rolling my eyes.The biggest issue I had was with the combat system. I built a warrior/rogue character because I wanted to enjoy some skill-based combat. However, I found that I was locked onto an enemy, it was difficult to switch between multiple targets with accuracy. This made it hard to block incoming attacks from the flanks or focus on different enemies. So I stopped locking onto enemies, but this made it extremely difficult to use the Assassin Rush skill as it required me to lock on to a target (which is almost random), use the skill, and then stop locking on. Destroys my groove.Also, the stealth mission at the beginning of the game is terrible.Needless to say, this was an amazing game for its time. However, I think replaying this game has made me realize and appreciate how much game design has advanced in the years since its release.So if you remember this being a great game, I suggest that you just hold on to those memories and spend your money on something else. I recommend something more recent.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												I always had heard the general misconception that Fable games are bad, or rather disappointing. I delved into this world looking for high fantasy with no questions asked, and it seemed like the right game for me. I kept seeing people saying 2 and 3 were bad, and that Fable the Lost Chapters was the best in the series, but I was still a bit, if not a lot, hesitant. I doubted and doubted, but I made up my mind and decided to purchase it and play it blind without knowing what is going on. As you may see I yet have to finish the game, but I cannot resist the need to just yell out how great, how excellent this game is. It strives for realism and achieves it in a "videogamey" way. It is action packed and the decisions to be good or evil are very fun. The world does change around you. People hail you if you're good and loathe you if you're evil, even running away from you. You can marry shallow but good-looking characters, and the game even makes fun of itself in this aspect on a book in which it incites you to murder your beloved just because you're bored of him or her. It is great, simply and absurdly great, and it was a real surprise for me to see this game be so good. 9/10 would give a wedding ring to the Guildmaster again.By the way, do not bother with anniversary, play this one, the real one, and see why it doesn't even deserve a remake.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												You should take my review with a big grain of salt because I was only able to play it for such a short while. But the reason for clocking out so soon was that the spinning camera angles gave me a really nasty motion sickness / migraine combo, and that means I can never go back to this game. No game has managed this spectacular feat since the 90's, so it's a huge minus in my book. Probably not a good game choice for anyone who's experienced similar problems with FPS / third person visuals. It's possible I would have endured longer in a console version, but I doubt it.In terms of gameplay, I was also immediately disappointed with... well, pretty much everything. The main character annoyed me from the start and I felt utterly disinclined to watch him grow into an even bigger bundle of annoyingness. Most importantly the hyped moral system was so blatantly black-and-white that it's just a bad joke. Seems to me there's not that much you can do to branch out from that, and I suspect the character changes would be mostly cosmetic.

Posted: September 4, 2014
												I've played Fable in so many ways over so, so many years. I was one of the poor fools waiting years for it to come out, and event hen I was kinda late to the party. All you really need to know is that this game -should- be awful. It failed the hype more than any other game in the history of ever (except maaaybe Duke Nukem Forever, because that one is awful), the graphics were not what they could have been, the combat shouldn't be fun, the voice acting is painful, the story is simplistic, and a few of the design decisions for models still hurt my brain.But the game is wonderful. For all that is 'missing', your mind is happy to fill it in, for all that combat should be a boring slog, every player will try a handful of weird rules and challenges, or, just goof off entirely, and get their fun. Collectibles are at once plentiful, and achievable without aid. Marriage is utterly pointless and unfulfilling. . .that's it, marriage is just pointless and unfulfilling. >.> Meta humor >.> Point is, there is no reason this game should be so awesome, and that's why it stands out as the shining beacon of "See here! This is what matters!" - Aesthetics. Every individual piece seems mismatched, disjointed, and frankly lacklustre on its own. Put them together and. . .you know the rest. Personally, I find this games sits with precious few others on that point of pure aesthetic gold, and among western-produced RPGs? It almost stands alone. Backing away from cartoonishness severely damaged the franchise, and I really do place 90% of the blame on that alone. I'm serious. If they remade Fable III, the exact game, but with Fable's graphics (and more important, use of graphics)? It'd be fine. Tho the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥map, weird hero retreat thing, and those damned guild seals to unlock chests vs. the old xp system would still be huge marrs, I think we could forgive a lot more if the game had just been charming. I'm buying Anniversary because I have to see it first hand. . . but looking at the screenshots honestly reminds me of when I heard the interview about how they finally had the tech to render lifelike creations in Phantom Menace, and used that to make Jar Jar Binks. . . . . What you do with what you got matters a helluva lot more . .tho I never liked Star Wars as a franchise because it's aesthetic has never appealed to me (too much metal >.>), and all it has to offer is the EXACT Hero's Journey, in space, with Buddhism. No thanks. I'll go read Saiyuki.

Posted: September 21, 2014
												With the heightened awareness of this due to Anniversary's release, I guess I'll give my opinion of this:Pretty sweet.Combat is pretty easy, but not quite as easy as Fable 2 and 3. If you dont buy Ressurectional Phails and dont wear Armour and don't put any points into the defensive skills, you end up with ♥♥♥♥ing hard combat though. Basically go full YOLO and ♥♥♥♥ defenses if you want to have to actually think in combat.That being said, there are a few gamebreakers. Basically the physical shield spell. With maxed mana pool that spell becomes basically god mode. I'd suggest not using it.Besides that, you have pretty basic combat: Range, Melee and Magic weapons/spells are all availiable for use at any time, similar to Kingdoms of Amalur (except Amalur's skill and combat system is superior in every way and you should be playing Amalur as it is basically Fable 1 but will less herp derp and more polish.). This allows you to use all of your weapons and spells without constantly go through menus and such. Overall pretty sweet.The game itself has charm in both its age, its somewhat unusual aesthetics, and probably a bit of nostalgia too. Going evil is especially funny as you just become more cartoon villian than anything. Even slaughtering an entire town doesnt feel like it has any real rammifactions, which is hilarious in its own right. It eventually comes down to standing in the middle of Oakvale with a badass sword killing an endless stream of guards before getting bored, sheathing your weapon and leaving to the adjacent town, who doesnt recognise nor care that you just killed like 100 dudes.There are downsides though: Spellcasting is based heavily on the system introduced for the Xbox, that is, only having a limited number of buttons compared to the larger number of spells. Get used to scrolling through pairs of owned spells. At the very least the game has the courtesy to let you organise these pairs. I cant remember if you can use the number keys for spells, you might - but don't take my lack of a conclusive answer sway you towards the 'it does'. Additionally the spells themselves are pretty hit and miss. Lightning is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max rank it and then you become the ♥♥♥♥ing god of lightning. Fireball is weak as ♥♥♥♥, until you max it, and you stand around charging it up to max damage while hoping you dont get interupted - that is to say, you will. Divine power/Infernal fury (or whatever thier names were) are OP as hell and basically become the only offensive spell worth noting at high level, even if it has a huge charge time. Slow time is godly. Heal is useless because healing potions do more, dont cost mana, and dont waste skill points.I could continue, but you get the idea. You quickly realise that some of the spells are useful, others simply aren't. There is some degree of replayability in terms of going range/mage/melee or any mix of those (Multi-strike and Multi-arrow do exactly what they say and are really nice for Mage/melee and Mage/range hybrid playthroughs.) however the story itself isn't all that good for replayability, and the limited map space again limits it. Didn't stop me as a kid from playing this WAY too much though.Basically, it's a fun 'old' (depends on your definition of old I guess, but by modern standards I'd call it fairly old - definately not oldschool though. DEFINATELY NOT) RPG that is worth a shot for its pretty low cost.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												I used to play this game on Xbox when it was just Fable. The extra storyline in this version just blows away any other RPG i have played in quite a while. The only new-ish RPG that comes close to this game that has the same style of play would be Fable 2, yes i know its the same people but thats the thing noone else makes a game quite as good as this IMO. So lets go over the 4 categories I like to write my reviews on (other than Combat Arms, doesnt even deserve the time anymore, yes it used to deserve it). Now onwards,1) Graphics 8/10Obviously the graphics are going to look and seem old, but thats one fo the tings i love about this game. It gives the game a classic feeling. If you prefer older textures that dont look all 8-bit then this game has just the right graphics for you. (I would do 10/10 but I do have to take in to account some glitchy textures like your hair looking wiry, etc.)2) Storyline 12/10 (HOLY SH#T)This games storyline will suck you in and make you feel as if you were living it. The narration is just amazing giving you in depth background and current information on whats happening. In the very beginning you start off as a boy trying to get a present for your sisters birthday so you go around doing good deeds so your father will pay you for them (1 gold piece per good deed). *SPOILER ALERT* If you havent played skip to the next rating, After your sister gets her present she knows something is not quite right. You hide in a field while the entire village you knew and loved is being burned and its people slaughtered. A guild master comes and rescues you and you start training as a hero from there on out the story gets more complex and interesting. By far, one of the best storylines I have EVER had the PRIVILEGE to play.3) Character development 7.5/10Yeah this game is slightly lacking in chracter development. You get more famous, you get good or evil, and you choose all your skills. This might sound incredibly amazing but the way they chose to lay it all out is slightly boring. You doo good or bad deeds your alignment changes (obviously). As your alignment changes you get horns and red mist if your evil and butterfllys and a halo if your good. You skills are Strength, Skill, and Will. Stregth is your health, damage and damge taken. Skill is speed, guile(sneakyness), and damage you do with cross/bows. Will is actually the main thing I loved as far as the character development go's hence the 7.5, You are able to choose skills that heal you, damage your foes, make you do more damage, make you take less damage, among an array of other spells you can buy all of them (eventually) for your experience. You earn experience based on which attack you use to deal with enemies and general experience that can be used for all three (skill,strength, and will) trees at your disposal. The alignment and renown is a little clunky but the Skills are very in-depth (if you dont like spending alot of time figuring out what works for you and what you like just stop playing RPGs their not for you)4) Gameplay 9.5/10This games gameplay is amazing as well. I cant give it a 10/10 however because of one tiny detail that I cant get over. When your stealing stuff and noone is looking at you but since they are in the same area you still get caught. THat is so unrealistic. If they didnt see you do it HOW ARE YOU IN TROUBLE. >:(I Anyways other than that the games mechanics and fighting are all very well thought out and its runs great on pretty much all computers (because its an older game).The fighting is in depth yet still easy to control and the other controls for just moving and using spells etc, are well thought out because you dont ahve to use complicated keyboard controls to kick a$$. Its that simple great mechanics make for a great game.OVER ALL RATING Should you play it: If you dont you should blow up your computer.Do I recommend this: YES but only to those people who are serious about RPG's because its a little in deptha and challenging if your not a RPG lover.Rating out of 100: 92.5/100 ( As far as im concerned no game will ever earn 100/100 from me (EVER)

Posted: August 31, 2014
												One of the best RPGs of the decade. Simple, yet beautiful. Fable's trademark is the fight between good and evil and the freedom that you, as the main hero, have to choose your own side. You can be evil from start to finish and literaly end the story in tragedy, instead of saving the world for selfish purposes, as it usualy is when you take an evil path in a RPG that has a happy ending regardless of your choices. Beign good, as always, also has its advantages and can be rewarding and fun. You'll feel like finishing the game more than once just to see the differences between playing the good and the bad guy. I've been playing and replaying this game throughout the years and it never gets old.Graphics, animations, gameplay and soundtrack still holds up, nothing feels dated or inadequade, even though the game is already ten years old. If you like action-centered RPGs, this one is for you.Gameplay - 8/10Soundtrack - 8/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 6/10Challenge Level - 3/10Replayability - 4/10

Posted: April 11, 2014
												So, what do you say about a game like Fable? As an RPG, it's shallow. As an action game, it's boring and repetitive. As a simulation, it's superficial. And as a story-driven game, well, the story is uninteresting. But you bring all these things together, along with a bit of unique charm and a good sense of humor, and you end up with something that's really a pretty good game. And even now, ten years after its original release, I'm still not sure there's another game quite like Fable. At any rate, I got it on sale, and I'd certainly say I got my buck-fifty's worth.

												A lot of my peers have written reviews, so I am going to express my opinion on the Steam version of Fable TLC. I remember being 11 years old and getting this game for Christmas for Xbox (yes, the original one) and thinking this cover looks cool, lets hope the story line holds up. My parents knew I was into the Sims and all that, so a decision game might be of my interest. Boy, were they right. This game allows for so many possibilities, and with TLC allows for the good guys to get a sword for being heroic (I had the first one, and I remember when I first beat the game and saved my sister, they were like "Oh, you were so herioc, giving up power like that" and not getting a major reward for it. Thankfully, this game has a reward, so no complaints there).If you are looking for a game to stear you down a storyline with little to no variance, this game will be disappointing. This game allows you to make choices and live with the consequences, being a hero, villian, or unprecedented acts of both. Out of all the Fables, this one is definitely worth replaying over and over again. When I found this game on Steam, I had to have it, just to relive some nostalgia of being a kid again. Thanks for reading. GreenEggsPwn

												A classic RPG released on PC with extra content as Fable: The Lost Chapters. This is arguably one of the most immersive western RPG games ever. It's famous for its customization and immersion of the player into the world. You can do just about anything in the world of Albion as your choices have an impact on the world around you. If you perhaps choose to get married and retire your life of heroics for the life of a familyman, nothing's to stop you! Almost anything is imaginable in the world of Albion as you can choose to become a heroic warrior or an evil warlord as you set upon a path that will affect everything around you in one way or another. Recommended for any fan of the RPG genre or anyone who likes immersion in their games.9/10

												Nostalgia.I played the original Fable as a kid on the Xbox and in my opinion Fable was easily TOP 3 best RPG's among the original xbox titles. Wether you're a kid, a teenager, or an adult, you've GOT TO BUY THIS GAME NOW!You'll really enjoy the in-game experience of creating your own story & crafting your Hero or Villain within the land of Albion. Posted: November 18, 2014
												First played this game on console around the time it came out. I was young and stupid, and ended up selling all of my clothing to the Guild shop vendor then wondering why I was running around naked. I quickly became better at this game, and learnt everything there is to know about it, and it's been keeping me entertained for years. All together I've probbaly played this game for about 1000 hours. The gameplay is fairly smooth, and the controlls aren't hard to get used to, although I personally enjoyed them a lot more on console. But if you're looking for a challenge, then this game might not be for you, although that can depend on how hard you make it for yourself. If you regularly level up and get the best weapons you can (which can be found pretty early) you'll blast through this game no problem, but if you stick with an iron sword and rarely level up, you'll have a bit of a tough time. You could always try and play through this game on the unnoficial "hardcore" mode and never level your character. The graphics are part of this game's charm. The textures are well done, well detailed, and the lighting is pretty nice to look at as well. The music is decent, but I found it's stuck with me over the years, while the actual game sounds are nicely done as well. No low quality, and they sound like they actaully fit with each action.This game is pretty short, if you do just one playthrough. You'd be lucky if you got more than 17 hours out of it, but there are tons of choices to make throughout the game, so there's a bit of replayability. There's a few easter eggs around as well, which are always nice to see. That's my review for Fable: The Lost Chapters. Hope you like it and hope you enjoy Fable as much as I do! :)

Posted: February 24, 2014
												This is a game that has been on my list for a long time. I've been a fan of Peter Molyneux's Black and White games, so I figured Fable would turn out good as well. I was lucky enough to find it on Amazon for $1 and immediately purchased it. The gameplay is decent and the ability to make yourself into the type of character that you want is nice. There are a few downsides. The graphics are less than great, but definitely playable. Also, the market/store side of things felt a bit limited. At any given moment in the game, you are set in a relatively small region of the country of Albion. The game isn't very wide open and feels like you are mostly just running along a bunch of paths betweens the little towns. Some of the side quests were repetitive such as escorting someone from A to B. Overall the game was fun, and I put in quite a few hours into it. If you can get it cheap, it is worth a play through. I would probably give it a 7.5/10.  The Anniversary edition of the game is coming out soon which might be a good alternative to this as it is essentially the same game with updated visuals.

Posted: August 16, 2014
												This game.This amazing game.The graphics are a bit dated but they hold up better than most from that era of games to an astounding degree, the design of enemies and characters, structures and weapons, they are all fantastic. The game has little choice other than good or evil, but this in my opinion aids the story allowing it to be tighter and more interesting than it otherwise may have been, and the story is ridiculous and so over the top its hard to express how much drama and comedy it mixed in to itself. The combat isnt perfect but the ability to mesh your magic in with melee and ranged combat is fun and keeps it interesting.All in all by soundtrack, gameplay, and story, vastly the best of a series the creators murdered shortly afterward.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I loved this game when I had it on Xbox. I have heard and seen it as being one of the most disapointing games of it's time, but I loved it. I went into the game blind, and loved it. I think it was because it was expected to be much more, but I was very happy where it was. It had plenty of action, a good story, great characters, and a lot of humor. It had a quite ElderScrolls feel to the leveling up. Instead of like most RPGs, where you get EXP from killing enemies and used that to level up, Fable is a bit different. You do get EXP from killing, but you also get it from doing the killing. You shoot something with an arrow, you get skill EXP. Blast them with lightning, you get will EXP. Bash them with a hammer, you get strength EXP. They do not mix together, so you can't play as pure mage and have a high health. Not from Will EXP, at least. This is where the General EXP come in, the stuff you get from killing and quests. That can be put towards anything. Also, what you do in the game effects your appearence. Like to crunch on little newborn chickens (yes, you can do that) and kill people? A red mist will rise from your feet and eyes, you will become pale, flies will be drawn to you like the corpses you leave behind, and you grow horns (also destroying the majority of your hairstyle). People will run in terror from you, and hate you though your power will keep them from doing anything. But if you play as good, people will flock to, you will get a halo and a beam of light when you stand still. I think your eyes change color, though it has been a long time. Max out strength and you will look like a bodybuilder. Will will make you glow. I can't remember what Skill does. Fighting badly leaves you with scars.I could keep going on, but you should play it yourself. My only complaints are that the GuildMaster gets annoying "Your health is low. Have you any potions, or food", and I am having trouble getting the game to run on my computer even though it should be able to run it no problem. But once I get it up and running I won't be doing much else.

												Fable - The Lost Chapters is a game bases on a small kid that lives in the town of oakvale one night his town gets attacked by bandits and he tries to flee but sadly see his parents die before his own eyes he then wants revenge and joins the hero's guild I quite enjoyed the game,once you start playing you just need to keep going,it's like a good book! the story isn't the strongest part of this game although i quite liked it.The game is now 8 years old and the graphics do show that a bit but there are worse looking games the graphics are very colorfull though and the big magic attacks look pretty good,also it means that this game runs great on old systems my pc has a gt 545 and it can run this game on maximum like a breeze There is a decent amount of choice in weapons although the blades and maces are way better then the bows and crossbowsthere also is a nice amount of armour sets to choose from but i do think that the ''magic'' combat needs a bit more attention.attack and armour wise.This games is also pretty short (played it out in around 12 hours) but you can keep playing a new secondary story after you defeat the final boss,but i dont think that will take to long also there are a couple of things that to bother me in this game1.theres a glitch/exploit how you can get unlimited money so basicly you can beat the game without taking a potion or anything 2.the mouth anymations are really really bad.3.The game world is a bit small,and there are a bunch of loading screens,they don't take very long so it isn't a big complaint.If you can pick this game up for cheap i would reccomend it,especially for those who like rpg's and fantasy games. i would give it a (6/10)

Posted: January 4, 2014
												 I have to say I wasn't to exited to play this game when I first started. I previously played Fable III and only bought the game after hearing the poplar complaint that Fable II and III had failed to live up standards of the first game. Firstly,  the opening tutorial was painful at times and the graphics are not the best thing this game has to offer, but once you get past that, Fable: The Lost Chapters is a truly enjoyable game. The combat system is fluid for melee, ranged, and magic alike, the leveling/experience system rewards you XP for not only defeating monsters and completing quest but also for which skills you used to do so. For explain, if I used magic abilities, whether they be combative or not, I would receive Magic XP, which I then could spend on buying or upgrading my magical talents.  Thus the more I use my skills, the better I will be at those skills. Another feature I liked was the ability to Boast. Just after you take a quest you have the ability to Boast about what you will do on said quest, for explain doing the entire quest with no clothes or without taking or doing damage, doing so increases gold you will receive at the completion of the quest while also providing a challenge for the journey ahead.  In order to truly get the Fable experience and better understand the series you must give this game a try.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is truly amazing, I freakin' love it! In my opinion, this is the only truly impressive game in the Fable series. In this game you play as The Hero Of Oakvale, a young child with dreams of greatness. The game sees you grow from a young punk, into a daring hero, dark warrior, or powerful mage. You can be anything you want in the game, you can even be a naked guy who runs around murdering people with a pic-axe! The game has fairly good graphics for the time, and I think they've aged fairly well.This game's soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks I've heard in an RPG! The theme tune was done by the amazing Danny Elfman, the same guy who did the music for the Spiderman trilogy and The Simpsons. The game allows true character evolution, as your character will evolve depending upon what skills you choose to focus on and your chosen allignment. For example, if you focus on building your strength skills you will become a big muscly giant. If you focus on being a good guy, you will look like Super Saiyan Goku. The game allows you to be whatever you want, and that's what I enjoy.The game does have problems though, and I'm going to avoid talking about the false advertising, because everyone has already bashed on it. One of the main annoyances I've had with the game is it's difficulty. It's way too easy, seriously! Five hours into the game and I'm able to bat everything away with zero effort! Almost all of the magic spells are overpowered and break the game. Do yourself a favor and avoid getting the Slow Time spell, it will kill any fun you can have. On top of that, there are various exploits in the game to get more powerful in a short amount of time. One such example is that the game features Ages potions, which give you a fair boost in EXP in a certain skill tree.The problem? If you have your combat multiplier up high enough and drink the potion, you'll get mad EXP for almost nothing! I had my combat multiplier at 14 and drank a potion, and got 14800 EXP in the will category! Also, the story was fairly predictable at times, and some of the characters seemed flat. I never really liked Briar Rose all that much, and Maze was just lame to me. I'd like Guildmaster more if he didn't pipe random advice into my ear every five seconds. And I found that some sidequests were either really lame, or didn't off much reward. One such quest is one where I have to acquire for blue mushrooms to cure a sick child, but the reward wasn't really that great in the grand scheme of things.Despite all that, I highly reccomend this game! If you're new to open-world RPGs and are on the fence of getting into these kinds of games, Fable would be a good starter for you. It isn't as large or as immerssive as Oblivon, Fallout 3, or Kingdoms Of Amalur, but you'll still get some bang out of your buck. Fable introduced me to the world of action RPGs, and I will never regret buying this game used back in the day. When this game goes on sale, I highly suggest picking it up. One final thing to note: This game does not have a difficulty slider, so you're stuck with the preset difficulty. Like said, it's easy but totally worth the price tag.

Posted: August 16, 2014
												I remember the year or so preceding the original Xbox release of this game, my young, nubile self was so entranced by the promises and words of Peter Molyneux, I had actually taken the task of hyping the game to other people upon myself.I was excited for oh so many of the words that slipped through his thin, snakelike lips, I didn't even begin to doubt a word he said.He promised deforestation based on the choices you make, industrialization, and vastly different stories and endings all based on some large choices and smaller things based on smaller choices.Being the young pepe I was, I never doubted anything he said, not even for a second.Then the game came out and I was forced to buy ♥♥♥♥ing chocolate for my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sister, sit through another 2 hour tutorial and then only another 45 minutes until I could leave Bowerstone, only to get another hour long quest chain that was still essentially the tutorial.Oh, a few choices I made had an imact, to be sure, like that guy isn't dead now and gives me some money, but in the end, Petey M lied about 60% of the promises he made. The environments never changed throughout the course of the story and there were no huge differences between being a saintly fella or a gigantic♥♥♥♥♥♥The combat is not exciting, this version looks pretty awful, the audio is all screwed up in many places and it controls like herpes all over your hands.This game single handedly made me into a gigantic, cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and made me hate video games.This game is why I have no friends, since after all my former friends bought the game with their allowance money, they beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me for making them waste their money.Peter Molyneux ruined my life.7/10 it's okay there's some charm to the game

												First off don't class yourself as a true RPG gamer if you've never played this.Firstly this game is the reason I play so many RPGs to date, I played it non-stop on my original XBOX and it never got old and a fewyears later I came across it on here hence the play time.Okay so first the graphics, admittedly by now they are WAY outdated and but don't let that deter you from a true RPG experience. Posted: July 2, 2014
												One of my favorite roleplaying games of all time. Originally owned it on the Xbox before the additional 'Lost Chapters' version came out. I saw this version on sale during the Steam Summer Sale and thought to myself, I can't go wrong repurchasing a game, with further expanded story content for a mere $3.39 at the time. Easily was worth every penny, as I got over 29hrs out of it on my replay, thus far.          I must say, even years later as an adult, grown up from my childhood, I can still revel in the excellent gameplay/story. This game was supposed to be monumental and break the mold for choices in a game, easily succeeding in the task, inspiring future games in the genre to come. Thusly, if you are a fan of RPGs and open world combat, feel free to pick this gem up. If anything, I can thoroughly endorse this game, with a lifelong gamer's seal of approval. Have fun in Albion if you found this review helpful.                                                                                                                                                                          10/10 - James

Posted: June 27, 2014
												At first glance this game just looks like your average RPG, but further research shows that it is much much more than that. First off in Fable every character has enormous hands and feet, don't let this turn you off, and really small teeth. The game looks great for something that was released 10 years ago that is if you're okay with original xbox level graphics. The game feels natural once you learn all of the controls but if you're playing on a laptop GET A MOUSE or else the game will be frustrating to the max. The music in this game is just generic RPG music so don't expect to be blown away by fully orchestrated tracks. Also the voices in this game are laughably bad for example many NPCs speak with a cocny accent which really grinds my gears, but that's just me. In addition to that whenever your health is low an old man nags you to eat food or use a healing potion, yeah I heard you the first time just let me live my life. While this game is no Zeld: Ocarina of Time it's a fun jaunt into an unoriginal fantasy world. Get it whenever it's on sale, you may or may not be sorry.

You wll spend hours playing through the same game, this time being the sneaky bowman rather than the evil hammer man. It offers play beyond the end and even an expansion pack! I BECAME THE CHICKEN CHASER. I was the legendary hero that saw his own village massared before his eyes, had his sister get her eyes sliced out, and father well he was kind of a wimp. Anyway each playthrough is definatley one of a kind. My favorite thing to do is bring people to the chapel of skorm and sacrifice them. Ahh the pleasure I derive. Plus you can fish until midnight! Skorm's bow brings warmth to my heart as it helps me erradicate the wonderful people of albion and still walk around with a halo.I have sunk so many hours into playing this game and would not tell you it was a good game if I did not believe it. It is worth every penny because you will get so much out of this game. and remember when your health is low have some food or potions. -Chicken chaser! haha he chases chickens!!-

												Nostalgia.I played the original Fable as a kid on the Xbox and in my opinion Fable was easily TOP 3 best RPG's among the original xbox titles. Wether you're a kid, a teenager, or an adult, you've GOT TO BUY THIS GAME NOW!You'll really enjoy the in-game experience of creating your own story & crafting your Hero or Villain within the land of Albion. Every choice you make shall determine your alignment, thus altering your appearance. As you complete quests and perform good or bad deeds, the people of Albion will begin to recognize you everywhere you go. Will you be feared, or loved?...and hey, why not stop by at the Pub and gamble over some Table Coin Golf? Buy a round a beers for everyone & fancy your luck with the ladies. Hell, why not marry a fine woman in every town across the land!

Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is truly amazing, I freakin' love it! In my opinion, this is the only truly impressive game in the Fable series. In this game you play as The Hero Of Oakvale, a young child with dreams of greatness. The game sees you grow from a young punk, into a daring hero, dark warrior, or powerful mage. You can be anything you want in the game, you can even be a naked guy who runs around murdering people with a pic-axe! The game has fairly good graphics for the time, and I think they've aged fairly well.This game's soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks I've heard in an RPG! The theme tune was done by the amazing Danny Elfman, the same guy who did the music for the Spiderman trilogy and The Simpsons. The game allows true character evolution, as your character will evolve depending upon what skills you choose to focus on and your chosen allignment. For example, if you focus on building your strength skills you will become a big muscly giant. If you focus on being a good guy, you will look like Super Saiyan Goku. The game allows you to be whatever you want, and that's what I enjoy.The game does have problems though, and I'm going to avoid talking about the false advertising, because everyone has already bashed on it. One of the main annoyances I've had with the game is it's difficulty. It's way too easy, seriously! Five hours into the game and I'm able to bat everything away with zero effort! Almost all of the magic spells are overpowered and break the game. Do yourself a favor and avoid getting the Slow Time spell, it will kill any fun you can have. On top of that, there are various exploits in the game to get more powerful in a short amount of time. One such example is that the game features Ages potions, which give you a fair boost in EXP in a certain skill tree.The problem? If you have your combat multiplier up high enough and drink the potion, you'll get mad EXP for almost nothing! I had my combat multiplier at 14 and drank a potion, and got 14800 EXP in the will category! Also, the story was fairly predictable at times, and some of the characters seemed flat. I never really liked Briar Rose all that much, and Maze was just lame to me. I'd like Guildmaster more if he didn't pipe random advice into my ear every five seconds. And I found that some sidequests were either really lame, or didn't off much reward. One such quest is one where I have to acquire for blue mushrooms to cure a sick child, but the reward wasn't really that great in the grand scheme of things.Despite all that, I highly reccomend this game! If you're new to open-world RPGs and are on the fence of getting into these kinds of games, Fable would be a good starter for you. It isn't as large or as immerssive as Oblivon, Fallout 3, or Kingdoms Of Amalur, but you'll still get some bang out of your buck. Fable introduced me to the world of action RPGs, and I will never regret buying this game used back in the day. When this game goes on sale, I highly suggest picking it up. One final thing to note: This game does not have a difficulty slider, so you're stuck with the preset difficulty. Like said, it's easy but totally worth the price tag.
